title: Looking for a job in a recession? Here's the advice this career coach gives her clients.
description:
• The job market isn't looking so rosy as companies and DOGE lay off workers.
  • However, it's not impossible to find a job with the proper preparation.
  • Career coach Marnie Lemonik shares the advice she gives her clients.

Recession fears, DOGE cuts, broad layoffs — It's a tough time to be looking for a job.

But it's definitely not impossible, and there are certain steps you can take to make sure your next job is more resilient to volatile economic conditions, according to career coach Marnie Lemonik.

Big companies like Meta and Blackrock have announced plans to cut down their workforce numbers this year. Unemployment has ticked up slightly from 3.9% a year ago to 4.1% now. And while DOGE layoffs didn't lead to a spike in unemployment claims in February, they could start showing up in next month's data, according to Shruti Mishra, an economist at Bank of America. Uncertainty around DOGE and tariffs could also lead some employers to pause hiring, Mishra added.

The choppy economic environment doesn't paint a rosy picture for those who are looking for a new job. However, it hasn't deterred some people — namely, Gen Z workers. In fact, the prevalence of layoffs might further incentivize some workers to start recruiting.

"The sentiment that I'm hearing from clients is 'I don't really feel a lot of stability,' and so that loyalty to a company for any given amount of time or reason is just less relevant because no one feels like they're getting that loyalty from the employer side," Lemonik said.

Here's the advice Lemonik gives her clients who are looking for jobs right now.

Be prepared

Lemonik's clients are exercising more caution in today's job market than they did in previous years.

Last year, it wasn't uncommon for Lemonik to see burnt-out clients quit their jobs with nothing lined up.

"Even a year ago, I felt like I was working with more people that were like, 'I'm really burned out at my job, and if I don't have another job in 3 months, I think I'm still going to take a break,'" Lemonik said.

Now, she's seeing more hesitation from her clients. "It's less so that people are gripping to the job that they have, but more so that they're not willing to take that risk of leaving without another job," Lemonik added.

One of the most common questions Lemonik's clients ask her when they interview for jobs is how they can determine if the job is safe from layoffs.

The biggest takeaway that Lemonik shared? You can't definitively predict if a job is "stable" or "safe."

"I think we all have to have some stability within ourselves in the way that we build our own career paths and financial safety nets because you can't put your stability or safety in any employer. This is my honest take that I give people," Lemonik told BI.

That's why it can be helpful to build up an emergency fund and evaluate your current budget to see where you can cut back on spending. Upskilling and investing in your career can also be ways to negotiate your salary at your next job and preserve job security in an economic downturn.

Ask smart interview questions

Lemonik tells her clients to take advantage of the opportunity to do their due diligence on a job when hiring managers ask, "Do you have any questions for me?"

"Could this be a department that's cut? Is this a smart type of role to be getting? Are these the first people out when there's no more budget left? These are the things people are trying to figure out," Lemonik said.

Asking the interviewer certain questions at the end of the interview can give you insights into how insulated the role is from economic volatility. Lemonik recommends asking about the direction of the company, as well as situational questions about how the company has dealt with challenges in the past.

She provided the following examples:

  • "I saw online that you guys are going through your Series E funding. I'd love to know what the biggest goal is for the coming year on the team, and if there are any obstacles to that goal, how you are currently handling them."
  • "I'd love to hear how you've handled a challenging time within the company in the past, and how you've helped your team rise above and maintain its culture as much as possible."

These questions allow you to examine if the role you're interviewing for has long-term growth potential. They also highlight what to expect from company leadership.

"I think anything you can do to explore how the leaders of the company operate when things are not as certain is a good indicator of how the company is going to react to potentially inevitable changes," Lemonik said.

Read the original article on Business Insider

title: Sam Altman did a good tweet
description:
• Sam Altman did a funny tweet about the popularity of OpenAI's latest feature.
  • ChatGPT will do images now, and people are using it to turn real photos into anime-style images.
  • "wake up one day to hundreds of messages: 'look i made you into a twink ghibli style haha'"

On Tuesday, OpenAI launched an image generator inside ChatGPT. In theory, this could create a world of new possibilities for art and creative expression.

In practice, people started immediately using it for one thing: turning their photos into a Studio Ghibli version. (Studio Ghibli is the anime studio behind movies like "The Boy and the Heron."

And, of course, after people turned themselves into anime, they moved on to other things.

couldn't resist pic.twitter.com/0i86Dq5xZA

— Granite Mtn. (@gran1te_mtn) March 26, 2025

You may have conflicted feelings about OpenAI's mission. You may be concerned with whether this image generator was trained on images that were improperly licensed or used without permission. That is all reasonable.

But you have to admit, this is a pretty funny tweet:

>be me
>grind for a decade trying to help make superintelligence to cure cancer or whatever
>mostly no one cares for first 7.5 years, then for 2.5 years everyone hates you for everything
>wake up one day to hundreds of messages: "look i made you into a twink ghibli style haha"

— Sam Altman (@sama) March 26, 2025

I just call it like I see it.

Tokyo Gas takes step back from growth-over-returns approach
description: Tokyo Gas had cut back on its previously high shareholder returns to fund long-term growth investments. (Photo by Kosuke Imamura) Utility readies $800m buyback as battery, shale gas investments raise profit concerns SHINO KATAYAMA March 27, 2025 07:05 JST TOKYO — Tokyo Gas will repurchase up to 120 billion yen ($800 million) in stock during the first half of fiscal 2025, the utility said Wednesday, in a shift back toward shareholder returns as major growth investments have struggled to bear fruit. The full amount would match the record 120 billion yen in buybacks the Japanese utility conducted in all of fiscal 2024, and do so in half the time. Tokyo Gas said it will consider further buybacks in the second half “based on company performance,” and raised its annual dividend for fiscal 2024 by 10 yen per share to 80 yen. “Though long-term growth is important to us, we cannot meet stakeholders’ expectations unless we focus to some extent on short-term economics,” President Shinichi Sasayama said in a briefing, adding that the company will “sincerely face” skepticism about its ability to achieve its fiscal 2025 target of 8% return on equity. A disclosure released last fall showed Elliott Investment Management owned more than 5% of Tokyo Gas. The activist investor has been pressuring the company to sell assets and return money to shareholders, a source familiar with the situation said. Once known for its high returns for shareholders, Tokyo Gas changed tack over the past few years, with Sasayama saying “we want to give back to shareholders through sustainable growth.” In fiscal 2020, the utility changed its shareholder payout ratio policy, lowering the target from around 60% to roughly 40% by fiscal 2023. Meanwhile, the company has outlined plans to spend 650 billion yen on growth investments in the three years through fiscal 2025, up from 475.8 billion yen in the preceding three years. During this pivot, Tokyo Gas invested in areas such as storage batteries and North American shale gas development, but has yet to see notable successes. Its return on assets, based on adjusted ordinary profit, came to 4.2% last fiscal year, 3.8 percentage points lower than in fiscal 2012. “Investment in fossil fuels makes money in the short term, but there’s a lot of uncertainty over the medium to long term,” an analyst said. “Investments in renewable energy and decarbonization are likely to become profitable in the medium to long term, but don’t make money now — they’re tough.” Tokyo Gas has pared its shareholder returns to keep funding investments with a long time horizon. Its domestic city gas business, which generates steady profits, has become a smaller part of the portfolio. S&P Global Ratings in November downgraded its outlook on the company’s long-term bonds from “stable” to “negative,” citing concerns about the possible impact of that shift on earnings and cash flow. Tokyo Gas is considering ways to boost profit while limiting outlays, such as acquiring usage rights to power generation and storage facilities owned by other companies. The utility plans to boost return on assets by divesting at least 100 billion yen in assets between fiscal 2025 and fiscal 2028.

title: Trump announces additional 25% tariff on foreign-made autos
description: U.S. President Donald Trump said auto tariffs will go into effect on April 2 and be on all countries. © Reuters White House expects over $100 billion in new annual revenues KEN MORIYASU March 27, 2025 06:46 JST WASHINGTON — U.S. President Donald Trump signed a proclamation imposing a 25% tariff on foreign-made cars and light trucks on Wednesday, in a move that the White House says will result in over $100 billion of new annual revenues. The tariffs will be charged in addition to ones that are already in place. The U.S. currently levies 2.5% on passenger vehicles and 25% on pickup trucks. “I think our automobile business will flourish like it’s never flourished before,” the president said, as he signed the order in the Oval Office. Trump said the auto tariffs will go into effect next Wednesday and apply to all countries. He added that auto parts that cross borders through the manufacturing process will not be subject to tariffs, but that such transactions will go down in the future. “For the most part, I think it’s going to lead cars to be made in one location,” he said. “Right now, a car would be made here, sent to Canada, sent to Mexico, sent all over the place. It’s ridiculous.”

title: Japan pension whale GPIF’s new chief brings bank expertise
description: Uchida will become the first GPIF head to hail from one of Japan's top banks. (Source photos by Nikkei) Kazuto Uchida has experience managing funds, working overseas Nikkei staff writers March 27, 2025 05:33 JST TOKYO — Japan’s Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF) will have a bank veteran with extensive experience on the front line of fund management as its new chief next month. Former Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group Director Kazuto Uchida will assume the top post at GPIF on April 1. “He has ample specialized knowledge and experience,” said Minister of Health, Labor and Welfare Takamaro Fukuoka at a Tuesday press conference announcing the appointment. Uchida will be the first GPIF head to hail from one of Japan’s top banks since the fund was established in 2006. GPIF, one of the world’s largest institutional investors, manages premiums paid to the country’s National Pension and Employees’ Pension Insurance system, with managed assets reaching 258 trillion yen ($1.71 trillion) at the end of 2024. It is often called a “whale” due to its investments’ sway on the market.  Uchida joined Mitsubishi Bank — now MUFG Bank — in 1985 and has long been involved in fund management. He was head of the section responsible for investing in yen assets, mainly Japanese government bonds. He also served as head of the market department, overseeing fund investment both at home and overseas for two years. He also served as chairman of Mitsubishi UFJ Morgan Stanley Securities. “He provides balanced and neutral analysis of the market and the economy in general,” said Nomura Research Institute’s executive economist Takahide Kiuchi, who knows Uchida well. “He is knowledgeable about banking in general and has management experience.” SMBC Nikko Securities analyst Hidenori Suezawa noted that Uchida “has an international background, having worked in the U.S.” He is expected to tackle two goals: securing investment returns and strengthening the organization. GPIF’s investment returns have been strong, with assets under management increasing 50% in the five years from the end of 2019 to the end of 2024. Success in pension asset management is judged by the effective yield — the difference between the rate of returns and the pace of nominal wage increases. GPIF’s stated target is 1.7%, with its actual results from fiscal 2001 to fiscal 2023 averaging 4.24% per year. The welfare ministry will raise the effective yield target to 1.9% from fiscal 2025. Many companies have announced wage increases, and nominal wage growth is expected to accelerate. As Japanese interest rates rise above zero amid inflation, GPIF is expected to produce higher returns. Securing workers is also an issue. As assets under management increase, the skills required for investment and risk management also become more advanced.

title: Asia needs to ensure power grids are in step with renewables growth
description: Technicians work to install a high voltage electric transmission line at the substation of Gujarat Solar Park in Gujarat, India on Sept, 12, 2024. © Reuters Upgrades are needed to unlock the full potential of wind and solar power projects Vandana Hari Vandana Hari March 27, 2025 05:05 JST Vandana Hari is founder of Vanda Insights, a Singapore-based global energy market intelligence provider. The recent boom in wind and solar power generation capacity has been hailed as a promising low-carbon solution to the world’s growing demand for energy, with governments doubling down on renewables as part of their net-zero emission targets. But a gaping hole has opened up in the execution of this strategy. Electricity grids around the world are struggling to integrate new solar and wind power projects — and the continued rapid growth in the latter will only make the situation worse. About 1,650 gigawatts of wind and solar projects in advanced stages of development around the world were waiting for grid connections as of July 2024, the International Energy Agency said in a February report. To put that in context, that figure is equivalent to around 52% of the current wind and solar capacity installed across the globe. Major developing economies in Asia are especially vulnerable to the downside of the growing disconnect between renewable power generation capacity and grid capacity due to multiple factors: A relatively high rate of urbanization spurring strong demand growth for power; the need for affordable, stable and accessible universal supply; rapidly growing reliance on oil and gas imports; and grid systems that are mostly government dominated. Investment in power transmission — the network of high-voltage power lines, substations, transformers and other infrastructure that moves electricity from power plants to the distribution networks that reach the final consumers — is woefully inadequate around the world, according to the IEA, but especially faces major funding gaps in developing economies. Countries looking to expand and upgrade their grids are also facing steep price hikes and long waits to get the critical components. On the supply side, there are limited equipment manufacturers globally, who in turn are struggling with supply chain bottlenecks, cost escalations and a shortage of skilled labor, leading to massive backlogs. Lead times for power transformers have doubled to four years and prices have rocketed 75% since 2019, while the waiting time for high-voltage cables has risen to three years and prices have nearly doubled since 2019, the IEA found. Grid integration is challenging for wind and solar projects because they are typically located in remote or rural areas, selected on the basis of access to land and sunlight or strong wind flows. As a result, they need the setting up of long-distance transmission networks — with the added complexity of underwater sea cables in the case of offshore wind — to deliver electricity to the grid. In contrast, coal- or gas-fired power plants are typically built near consumption centers, making them relatively easier to connect with existing high-voltage transmission networks. Intermittency in wind and solar projects — the loss of power output when the wind doesn’t blow and the sun doesn’t shine — needs balancing mechanisms such as battery storage or pumped hydro, and “smart grid” systems that can allow grid operators to anticipate and manage the fluctuations, all of which also needs considerable investment. China has built an industry to produce the full array of transmission and distribution system components but is using much of its manufacturing capacity to serve galloping domestic demand, according to the Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis. China added about 277 GW of new solar capacity in 2024, a 45% jump from 2023, and 80 GW of wind capacity for an increase of 18%. Southeast Asian countries, endowed with rich wind and solar power resources, need to avoid the trap of pursuing only one part of the renewables build-out equation while increasing their import dependency on an already stretched grid components sector. Workers install solar panels on Tseng Tien-fu’s vanilla farm in Taoyuan, Taiwan on May 30, 2022.   © Reuters As the IEEFA puts it, solar panels and wind turbines are “the most identifiable symbols of the energy transition,” and Southeast Asian governments have encouraged and even mandated local production of these components. At the same time, downstream policy incentives have stimulated fund inflows into construction of wind and solar power plants. But the electricity grid appears to have been neglected. Governments in the region need to heed growing calls from prominent energy policy and research organizations to create fully grid-integrated supply projects and localize grid equipment supply chains. “Investment in transmission equipment production could be pivotal in ensuring energy security, reliability and availability,” according to the IEEFA. The International Renewable Energy Agency has urged Southeast Asian countries to invest in modernizing and expanding grid infrastructure, with a focus on adopting advanced technologies for grid flexibility and energy storage systems needed to accommodate the growing share of wind and solar power generation. In most countries in the region — with the exception of the Philippines — state-owned enterprises control power transmission and often also have a monopoly or dominant role in power generation and distribution, with governments regulating electricity tariffs. Policymakers need to quickly figure out ways to manage the dichotomy between power grids as a legacy state-owned and state-managed part of the electricity ecosystem and the demands of private sector-led, fast-growing wind and solar generation. Whether it is done through state funding or with the help of private investment, the expansion, upgradation and modernization of power grids through digitalization needs to be prioritized. On the flip side, not doing so in time may spur an irreversible exodus of investors from wind and solar projects. Policymakers need to find ways to catalyze local manufacturing of power grid components. It could be done at a national level, or through overseas joint ventures with existing players and financing from multilateral development banks. A good starting point would be to bring the boring but critical backbone of power grids to the fore in policymaking and industry discussions, regionally and internationally. While renewables and other forms of “green” power generation have become common on the agenda of oil and gas conferences in recent years, the grid has remained in the shadows. It’s encouraging to see the second-ever edition of the Astana International Forum in Kazakhstan, planned for May 29 and 30, which aims at finding solutions to the challenges of climate change, food shortages and energy security, dedicating a session exclusively to nations ensuring power supply stability amid the intermittency of renewables and supply chain issues. More conferences and seminars focused on the entire power sector ecosystem from generation to distribution are needed to facilitate the exchange of know-how and spur collaboration opportunities among industry players, policymakers, investors and think tanks. This has become critical if we are to prevent the wind and solar power bandwagon from decoupling and derailing.

title: Japan’s Tokio Marine Asset exits net-zero alliance after BlackRock
description: Industry-based alliances working toward reaching net-zero emissions face headwinds as the Trump administration rolls back climate initiatives. © Reuters Industry climate initiative loses steam amid Trump rollbacks OKI HIDAKA and HARUKI KITAGAWA March 27, 2025 05:00 JST TOKYO — Tokio Marine Asset Management left an environmentally focused investor group at the end of February, Nikkei has learned, marking the first exit by a major Japanese player amid growing headwinds on global efforts to combat climate change. Tokio Marine Asset said it made the decision after reviewing the purpose of its membership, including whether participation in the Net Zero Asset Managers (NZAM) initiative was helping solve societal challenges. Tokio Marine Asset said it will not abandon contributions toward a creating decarbonized society. Other major Japanese asset managers, including Nomura Asset Management, Daiwa Asset Management and Mitsubishi UFJ Asset Management, remained part of NZAM as of Wednesday. Sompo Asset Management, which like Tokio Marine Asset is a subsidiary of a nonlife insurance group, is still also part of the framework. Overseas, U.S.-based BlackRock, the world’s biggest asset manager, exited NZAM in January, saying its membership “caused confusion regarding BlackRock’s practices and subjected us to legal inquiries from various public officials.” BlackRock has played a leading role in the sector’s efforts to address climate change risks. But Republican lawmakers have accused it of forcing green strategies on U.S. businesses. With U.S. President Donald Trump rolling back climate-related initiatives, BlackRock may be wary of drawing further criticism or losing business opportunities. Following BlackRock’s departure, NZAM said it would suspend activities while it reviews objectives and operations. It has also taken down its roster from the website. “Unless NZAM settles on its direction, we can’t decide on how we will respond as a company,” said an executive at a leading asset manager. Whether other Japanese players will follow Tokio Marine Asset remains to be seen. “We know there have been some departures overseas, but we can’t make the decision on our own since we manage assets belonging to other owners,” an industry insider said. “Depending on the situation, we may need to consider an exit,” said the head of one asset manager. In related fields, all three leading Japanese insurance groups, including Tokio Marine Asset’s parent, Tokio Marine Holdings, have exited the United Nations-backed Net-Zero Insurance Alliance. Six U.S. banks, including Goldman Sachs and Wells Fargo, as well as major Japanese players like Sumitomo Mitsui Banking , have left the Net-Zero Banking Alliance, another U.N.-backed group, since December.

title: Tesla to launch in Saudi Arabia as Musk and the kingdom mend relations
description: Tesla sells in other Middle Eastern countries, but not in Saudi Arabia. © Reuters Sales start in April, five years after feud with PIF over taking automaker private March 27, 2025 04:11 JST RIYADH (Reuters) — Tesla will start sales in Saudi Arabia next month, the electric carmaker said on its website, signaling CEO Elon Musk and the kingdom have healed a rift that dates back to the billionaire’s short-lived bid in 2018 to take the company private. Tesla sells in other Middle Eastern countries, but not in Saudi Arabia, the Gulf region’s largest market, where EVs only account for 1% of total car sales. The brand has had considerable success in neighboring United Arab Emirates, where most ride-hailing apps offer electric vehicles. The dispute started when Musk tweeted in 2018 he had “funding secured” to take Tesla private after a meeting with Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund, the Public Investment Fund. That tweet eventually led to a lawsuit from investors when a bid failed to materialize, during which tense text messages between Musk and PIF head Yasir al-Rumayyan were made public. Tensions have eased since the autumn, when Musk took a high-profile role in U.S. President Donald Trump’s election campaign and then new administration. Trump said this month he would likely make his first trip abroad to Saudi Arabia, after asking the kingdom in January to spend upward of $1 trillion in the U.S. economy over four years, including military purchases. EVs from China’s BYD and PIF-backed Lucid are already available in the Saudi market. EV sales have been slow in Saudi Arabia, with a 2024 report from consultants PwC putting them at just 1% of all car sales. Tesla’s launch event in Riyadh, scheduled for April 10, will display its EVs and products powered by solar energy, the post said. “Experience the future of autonomous driving with Cybercab, and meet Optimus, our humanoid robot, as we showcase what’s next in AI and robotics,” it added. On April 11, it will open pop-up stores in Riyadh, Jeddah and Dammam, Tesla said in a later statement, adding it would announce further details of its plans for Saudi Arabia in the coming weeks, with investment planned for 2025 and beyond. Invitations to the launch event asked guests to indicate which Tesla car model they were interested in. A month after the feud with Musk went public, the PIF announced a $1-billion-plus investment in Lucid, becoming the majority investor in one of the EV startups looking to challenge Tesla. PIF, which has assets under management of $925 billion, has also invested in a domestic EV brand that is yet to launch called Ceer. Yet large, gas-guzzling vehicles remain the norm on Saudi roads where fuel is cheap and EV charging infrastructure remains a rarity, making traversing its long desert roads almost impossible in an EV. The launch comes as Tesla has seen EV sales slump in Europe, blamed on Musk’s support for far right politicians, and the brand has been targeted by protesters in the United States over his spearheading of sweeping cuts to the federal government. In one of the first signs of improving relations, Musk appeared alongside Rumayyan and Trump in ringside seats at a UFC mixed martial arts match in New York in November. A few weeks earlier, Musk had made a surprise appearance at Riyadh’s Future Investment Initiative summit via video link. A U.S. jury found in 2023 that Musk was not liable for misleading investors when he tweeted funding was secured to take Tesla private. Musk testified it was the PIF that had wanted to take Tesla private when he posted that tweet, and a series of tense text messages between him and Rumayyan emerged during the case. “You are throwing me under the bus,” Musk wrote in a text to Rumayyan, according to court documents. Tesla’s sales in Europe are down 42.6% so far this year, data showed on Tuesday, even as demand for EVs rises. Activists across the U.S. have staged “Tesla Takedown” demonstrations over Musk’s role leading the Department of Government Efficiency, which has cut thousands of jobs, frozen foreign aid and canceled thousands of programs and contracts.

title: Analysis: Panama port deal puts ‘prophet’ Li Ka-shing to the test
description: Li Ka-shing might look like he is caught in the middle of a Donald Trump-Xi Jinping feud, but history shows he has a knack for maneuvering around politics and ahead of economic trends. (Nikkei montage/Source photos by Reuters and Yusuke Hinata) The Hong Kong tycoon's move comes as the U.S. and China ratchet up tensions KATSUJI NAKAZAWA KATSUJI NAKAZAWA March 27, 2025 04:00 JST Katsuji Nakazawa is a Tokyo-based senior staff and editorial writer at Nikkei. He spent seven years in China as a correspondent and later as China bureau chief. He was the 2014 recipient of the Vaughn-Ueda International Journalist prize. CK Hutchison founder Li Ka-shing has made his way back into the global spotlight by deciding to sell the rights to operate ports on either side of the Panama Canal, which has become a pain point in U.S.-China tensions. While the Hong Kong tycoon’s move might win him points in Washington, it has put him in Beijing’s crosshairs. But Li might not even feel the pressure. The 96-year-old billionaire has a well-established reputation for his ability to see what is likely to happen in the future and to take appropriate action. He is known to have correctly predicted a dramatic change in the Chinese real estate market and sold off many mainland assets before the country’s property bubble started to collapse in 2021. So has the man who has witnessed decades of fierce power struggles within the Chinese Communist Party made another prediction, one about U.S.-China relations? Li Ka-shing made inroads into China in the first half of the 1990s by deepening relationships with companies affiliated with the Ministry of Transport.   © Reuters Exactly 30 years ago, Li learned firsthand the dark side of Chinese politics through his involvement in a huge development project in Wangfujing, a busy shopping district in central Beijing. Wangfujing is not far from Zhongnanhai, the country’s political nerve center where party leaders have their offices. On April 4, 1995, gunfire rang out in a suburb of Beijing, and Wang Baosen, Beijing’s then-most senior vice mayor, was found dead. It is said he committed suicide by shooting himself in the head. Wang’s shocking death developed into a major corruption scandal that rocked Chinese politics. Shortly afterward, Chen Xitong, who was Beijing’s top official and a key member of the “Beijing faction,” was purged for corruption. Chen, who was a member of the party’s powerful Politburo, was eventually sentenced to 16 years in prison, and questions were later raised about whether his corruption charge had more to do with a serious crime. After the deadly Tiananmen Square crackdown on pro-democracy students in 1989, Jiang Zemin, then Shanghai’s top official, was suddenly tapped as the party’s general secretary. Jiang replaced Zhao Ziyang, who was purged in the wake of Tiananmen Square for showing a sympathetic attitude toward the protesting students. Jiang was “a new face” in Beijing. Although he had the backing of then-supreme leader Deng Xiaoping, his own political base was extremely weak. Jiang Zemin and Li Peng join a news conference at The Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Sept. 26, 1989. Jiang became the party’s general secretary that year.   © Reuters In essence, Chen’s downfall was the result of a dog-eat-dog power struggle within the party. Jiang, who led the “Shanghai faction,” drove Chen out to consolidate his power as the influential Beijing faction member had stood in his way. Chen’s corruption case involved Li’s massive development project in Wangfujing. Li must have felt his blood freeze as he was seen as being at the center of the case. But the case — in essence an outgrowth of a party power struggle — only impacted the Hong Kong tycoon temporarily. Li made inroads into China in the first half of the 1990s, after Tiananmen Square sparked harsh Western sanctions. He deepened his relationships with companies affiliated with the Ministry of Transport, including in the port and terminal business. Around the time of the 1995 corruption scandal involving Chen, Li began to forge an even closer relationship with Jiang, who won his power struggle and cemented his position as successor to the aged Deng. Connections to Jiang and those close to him who controlled China’s transport-related sectors were a tremendous asset for Li. They paved the way for China to support one of CK Hutchison’s subsidiaries to acquire the rights to operate the two Panama ports. Li was indebted to Deng and Jiang for helping his business expand in China and beyond. U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio tours the Miraflores locks at the Panama Canal in Panama City on Feb. 2. After the U.S. made the canal a point of contention between itself and China, Panama announced it would withdraw from the China-led Belt and Road Initiative in 2026. (Pool photo/Reuters) The CK Hutchison subsidiary acquired the rights from the Panamanian government in 1997. The handover of Hong Kong from the U.K. to China also took place that year. The ports in question are the port of Balboa on the Pacific side of the canal and the port of Cristobal on the Atlantic side. In 2021, four years after the U.K. handed over Hong Kong, China joined the World Trade Organization under Jiang, and U.S.-China trade quickly expanded. As a result, CK Hutchison’s profits from operating the Panama ports grew. This trend accelerated during the era of Jiang’s successor, Hu Jintao, as the Chinese economy grew rapidly. But China, its economy and the world it exists in have drastically changed since Xi Jinping took over from Hu as party general secretary in 2012. The change in U.S.-China relations has been especially dramatic. When Donald Trump, who in January was inaugurated for a second term as U.S. president, declared he would take back the Panama Canal, CK Hutchison faced the possibility of becoming a direct target. Despite Trump’s threat coming suddenly, it was not long before Panama announced it would withdraw from the China-led Belt and Road Initiative in 2026, when its memorandum of understanding with China to cooperate on the global infrastructure drive is due to expire. With Panama more or less bowing to Trump, suddenly the threat to CK Hutchison became all the more real. Li moved quickly. On March 4, his conglomerate signed an agreement to sell its non-Chinese port assets, including the two Panama Canal ports, to a consortium led by U.S. asset management firm BlackRock. An unhappy Xi administration responded to the announced deal, albeit indirectly, after the National People’s Congress, China’s national legislature, ended its annual session on March 11. The Hong Kong and Macao Work Office of the party’s Central Committee reposted on its website a harshly critical article published in Ta Kung Pao, a Chinese government-affiliated Hong Kong newspaper. This commentary published by Ta Kung Pao suggests it is “understandable” that many would view the Panama deal as a betrayal of the Chinese people. (Photo by Kenji Kawase) The article lashed out at the deal, claiming it would undermine China’s national security and interests. Ta Kung Pao also published a commentary calling for CK Hutchison to halt the transaction and suggesting the deal would violate the national security ordinance, which took effect in Hong Kong a year ago. It remains unclear whether Beijing’s indirect pressure could lead to CK Hutchison reconsidering its decision. CK Hutchison is a private company, not state-owned. The conglomerate is huge but does not have the power to shrug off the political risk that comes from being caught between the world’s two largest economic foes. Although the Xi administration often stresses the need for “patriotism” and “national security,” there is no way it could protect CK Hutchison from the pressure that would be piled onto it by a determined U.S. Three decades ago, with the handover looming, Hong Kong companies began moving closer to mainland China under a “one country, two systems” formula that promised “a high degree of autonomy” for the former British colony. Deng firmly pledged to keep the formula unchanged for 50 years after the handover. Jiang and Hu maintained the guarantee, which has since disintegrated. In the new political reality, it is only natural for Hong Kong merchants to behave differently. Li was born in China’s Guangdong province, adjacent to Hong Kong, in 1928. His long life has allowed him to observe many chapters of Chinese history. The lessons he has taken away have taught him how to be quick to seize an opportunity. Li Ka-shing, chairman of CK Hutchison Holdings, waves goodbye to journalists as he formally retires after the company’s annual general meeting in Hong Kong on May 10, 2018. Li would burnish his reputation as “a prophet” some three years later.   © Reuters He has also gained the ability to correctly predict where China’s economy and politics — and the international political and economic situations surrounding China — are headed. He demonstrated his foresight by gradually selling off many of his mainland property holdings after Xi became China’s top leader. Prominent Chinese real estate moguls were paying attention to the Hong Kong billionaire’s low-profile asset sell-off, and some of them also escaped the implosion unscathed by following Li’s example. As a result, Li’s reputation as “a prophet” became rock-solid. This time, Li has decided to divest CK Hutchison’s operating rights for many overseas ports even as they generate profits. Will this also prove prescient?

title: Kikkoman’s use of U.S. ingredients makes its soy sauce tariff-proof: CEO
description: Kikkoman has produced its soy sauce in the U.S. for over 50 years. (Photo by Momoko Imamura) Japanese seasoning maker sees American market having room to double MOMOKO IMAMURA March 27, 2025 01:46 JST TOKYO — Japanese soy sauce maker Kikkoman is not concerned about President Donald Trump’s plans to impose additional tariffs as its containers and raw materials are all produced in the U.S., President and CEO Shozaburo Nakano told Nikkei. Edited excerpts from the interview follow. Q: North America accounts for more than 60% of Kikkoman’s consolidated operating profit. How do you see Trump’s tariffs impacting your business? A: Our soy sauce is made and sold with American ingredients and materials, so it is not affected by tariffs. As soy sauce has a low unit price per weight, it is difficult to make a profit unless it is produced locally, so we have done so for over 50 years and made it a part of the American diet. Kikkoman CEO Shozaburo Nakano told Nikkei the company looks to expand its reach in the U.S. to more Latin American and younger consumers. (Photo by Momoko Imamura) The soy sauce we make in Japan uses ingredients from North America, so it is affected by exchange rates and other factors. In our food wholesale business, we would like to increase the proportion of products made in the U.S. Many of our rice and seafood products are produced in the U.S. We also export products from China and Southeast Asia, so we will be affected by tariffs there, but our competitors are in the same boat, so we’re not worried. By increasing the number of products made in the U.S., we can shorten the entire supply chain and ensure a stable supply. Q: Your new U.S. factory will be start operating from 2026. A: Our production capacity in the U.S. is expected to increase 30% to 40% over the next 10 years. Demand in the U.S. is still growing, and we believe the market has room to double. The growing Latin American population prefers products containing fruit juice, so we will develop products that meet their tastes. We will also reach young people through social media and other means to expand our customer base. Q: In Europe, the supply of soy sauce failed to keep up with the growing demand. A: When demand fell overall due to the coronavirus pandemic, we held back on capital investment. With Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and the European economic slump, we grew cautious, which ended up backfiring. Demand returned last year, and we managed to ship some supply from Singapore and Japan, but the costs were high. We are making capital investments, and our supply capacity will catch up with demand in six months. Q: Kikkoman’s net profit for the year ending March 2025 is expected to rise 9% for the 12th consecutive record. What’s your outlook for next fiscal year? A: We are finished with our prices hikes in Japan, but sales volumes have not returned to the levels before we adjusted prices. We will work on increasing volume by suggesting recipes. We will work to raise sales volume to improve profit margins. To cope with rising logistics costs, we are increasing cargo loads and factory productivity. Raw ingredient prices are already high, so we do not expect to see significant cost increases like we have before. Q: Kikkoman’s return on equity (ROE) for the year ended March 2024 was 12.5%, already exceeding the target of 11% or more for the year ending March 2025. A: We will continue to raise our ROE. Our cash has increased, and our equity ratio has also risen. In addition to capital investment, we are also focusing on returning profits to investors through share buybacks and other means. We are also reducing our cross-shareholdings, including by dissolving our capital tie-up with [food processing company] Riken Vitamin, so we now have some financial leeway. We would also like to pursue an acquisition if we see an opportunity.

title: Half of top Japan business leaders eye U.S. expansion: survey
description: The 25% tariffs on steel and aluminum products implemented by the U.S. in March impose additional costs on Japanese companies. © Reuters Executives worry about tariffs and labor costs, stay the course on DEI policies TAKEHIRO HASEGAWA March 27, 2025 01:36 JST TOKYO — Nearly 50% of leaders at major Japanese companies look to ramp up U.S. operations amid President Donald Trump’s efforts to draw foreign investment, but many worry about the uncertainty surrounding his administration’s tariff plans, a Nikkei survey shows. Of the 144 companies that provided responses, 28.3% said they plan to expand in the U.S., with another 20.5% considering doing so, while 0.8% have no presence there now but will enter the market going forward. None intend to scale back U.S. business. About three-quarters of the companies eyeing expansions cited sales as a part of their plans, followed by production at 50.8%, mergers and acquisitions at 47.6%, and startup investment at 34.9%. Among individual industries, electrical equipment, food, and machinery and materials were standouts. The U.S. is expected to see medium- to long-term growth across a broad range of markets, including IT, energy and food, providing business opportunities for the high-value-added products and services that are a specialty of many Japanese companies. Nissin Foods Holdings will start up its first U.S. instant-noodle plant in 47 years this August. Sumitomo Chemical plans to build a production facility for a cleaning solvent used in semiconductor manufacturing. The Trump administration has been working to attract foreign capital to revitalize domestic industry. Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba said last month that Japan will work to boost investment in the U.S. to $1 trillion, and businesses are following his lead. A total of 41.4% of leaders said in the survey, conducted from Feb. 28 to March 19, that they plan to expand investments in the U.S. or make new ones, a sharp jump from 16.9% in the previous December survey . Yutaka Kyoya, president of food wholesaler Mitsubishi Shokuhin, said he hopes the Japanese government will provide “tax breaks to support direct investment in the U.S.” But deep concerns remain about Trump’s planned tariffs, which would impose additional costs on businesses that import products, parts or consumable goods from covered countries into the U.S. and could drag down the economy in the short term. The Trump administration this month implemented an additional 25% duty on steel and aluminum products . Policy uncertainty was the most commonly cited challenge involved in expanding in the U.S., mentioned by 73% of the executives polled. The Trump administration has repeatedly pushed back implementation of announced tariffs, and the reciprocal tariffs to be announced April 2 may end up being limited to certain countries or products. “Given the need to curb inflation ahead of midterm elections as well, it’s not clear how much they’ll keep raising tariffs,” said Suntory Holdings Chairman Takeshi Niinami. Business leaders also remain wary of production transfers that involve investment. Asked about how they intend to respond to the tariffs, nearly half of 84 companies surveyed that are in the manufacturing sector or have production divisions said they will maintain the status quo or wait and see how things develop. Tariffs are not the only concern. “There will probably be companies that give up because it’s not worth the soaring labor costs in the U.S.,” said Hideo Kumano, chief economist at the Dai-ichi Life Research Institute. Executives were also asked about diversity, equity and inclusion (DEI), amid hostility from the Trump administration that has spurred companies like McDonald’s, Walmart and Amazon to end or scale back their DEI policies. But 86.6% of respondents say they will not change their DEI guidelines in North America, while only 8.4% plan to make or are considering changes such as dropping the term DEI. Promoting DEI “is crucial for sustainable growth,” Kubota President Yuichi Kitao said. Japan has been relatively laggard with regard to women in the workforce and LGBTQ issues, and most of corporate Japan’s diversity-related targets focus on women. “DEI in Japan still has room for improvement compared with other advanced economies,” Sumitomo Chemical President Keiichi Iwata said. President Akihiko Ogino of Daiwa Securities Group said: “Now, when the global trend is slowing down, is the perfect time for Japanese companies to catch up.”

title: Vingroup to pour up to $30bn into renewables, LNG power in Vietnam
description: Most of Vingroup's $30 billion investment in energy infrastructure will go toward renewables, such as wind power. (Photo by Yuji Nitta) Nation's leading conglomerate looks to build out energy infrastructure YUJI NITTA March 27, 2025 00:47 JST HANOI — Vietnamese conglomerate Vingroup plans to spend up to $30 billion on renewable energy projects and a liquefied natural gas-fueled power station. The massive investment plan was included in a proposal from Vingroup — sent to government leaders — to develop Vietnam’s power grid, according to local media reports. Vingroup expects to install 25.5 gigawatts worth of power capacity during the first phase of the development project, which runs through 2030. This phase would cost between $25 billion and $30 billion. The majority of the investment would be directed toward renewable energy, such as wind and solar power. More than $20 billion would be invested in developing 20.5 GW worth of capacity in this field. Planned construction sites include Ninh Thuan and Khanh Hoa provinces. Waters stretching from central to southern Vietnam are seen as promising areas for wind farms. For LNG power, Vingroup has proposed building an electrical plant in Haiphong with a capacity of 5 GW. The northern port city is home to a Vingroup-affiliated electric vehicle factory, as well as large real estate developments under the group’s umbrella. Vingroup plans a second phase where it will develop 27 GW of power capacity between 2031 and 2035. The plan is currently being studied, a Vingroup representative told Nikkei. Vietnam’s Ministry of Industry and Trade is busy revising the country’s eighth national Power Development Plan, also known as PDP8, which outlines the basic policy for electrical plants and the power grid. The agenda includes the construction of nuclear power plants, as well as a road map for expanding renewable energy. Vingroup’s proposal is aimed at encouraging the addition of its own projects to the modified PDP8. The government expects Vietnam’s gross domestic product to grow by at least 8% this year and aims to surpass 10% growth in the near future. Developing sources of power would meet the increased electricity demand that generally accompanies economic growth.

title: Japan and Brazil agree on climate cooperation during Lula’s state visit
description: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba, right, shakes hands with Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva during the March 26 summit in Tokyo. (Pool via Reuters) Brazil's biofuels and Japanese autos to help reach carbon neutrality, Ishiba says KANA BABA and NIKI MIZUGUCHI March 27, 2025 00:43 JST TOKYO — Japan and Brazil agreed on Wednesday to cooperate in areas including the economy and climate change during a meeting between Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba and President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. The two sides drew up a five-year action plan covering those areas. The two nations also agreed on reciprocal visits by leaders every two years and confirmed the establishment of a new defense and foreign affairs dialogue. Holding a meeting with Japan is critical at this moment in history when democracy is under threat worldwide, Lula said at the start of the summit at the Akasaka Palace state guest house in Tokyo. The Brazilian president stressed the importance of multilateralism and free trade for mutual development. Ishiba sounded a similar note during the joint press conference following the summit. “We confirmed that we’ll launch a partnership aimed at strengthening peace and multilateralism, and deepen dialogue and cooperation in areas such as security and defense,” he said. Japan and Brazil are drawing closer in a strategic move as global stability is shaken by the return of U.S. President Donald Trump as well as alliances among authoritarian nations such as China and Russia. This year marks the 130th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between Japan and Brazil. Lula is the first state guest invited to Japan since 2019, when Trump received the reception during his first term. Ishiba and Lula agreed to use Japan’s official development assistance to recover Brazil land abandoned due to deforestation and slash-and-burn agriculture. The aim to turn the land into high-quality farmland. The two leaders also agreed to begin negotiations on a “working holiday” program that lets young people from Japan and Brazil work and stay in the other country for extended periods. On economic cooperation, the two countries will tap Brazil’s biofuels and Japan’s automotive technology to “lead the decarbonization of the global automotive sector,” Ishiba said at the press conference. Prior to the summit, government officials and companies from the two nations signed about 80 memorandums of understanding covering areas such as decarbonization and digitalization. Ishiba and Lula attended a business forum in Tokyo and welcomed the signings. Lula said that the Japan and Mercosur, the South American trade bloc, should advance talks toward a free trade agreement. Among the memorandums signed on Wednesday, Yokohama-based Tsubame BHB will work with Brazilian counterparts on using green ammonia for fertilizer. The green ammonia will be made from waste created from processing sugarcane, a raw material for bioethanol. Trading company Sumitomo Corp. will roll out technology that keeps pork fresh longer during transport. Air carrier ANA Holdings signed a memorandum to buy aircraft made by Embraer, the Brazilian plane manufacturer. Ishiba noted that Japan’s direct investment in Brazil from last year totaled 1.3 trillion yen ($8.64 billion). “This is the true reflection of the anticipation that Japanese companies have for Brazil,” the prime minister said. Japan has imported core commodities such as iron ore and soybeans from Brazil, South America’s largest economy. In return, Japan have exported industrial products such as auto parts. Tokyo also sees Brazil as crucial to working with developing and emerging Global South economies. Brazil is a member of the BRICS group of emerging economies, which includes Russia, China and India, but shares common values with Japan, including the rule of law and international cooperation. With a history of taking in Japanese immigrants, Brazil has roughly 2.7 million people of Japanese descent — the most in the world outside of Japan. Tokyo regards the new five-year plan as reaffirming their commitment to work together with an eye toward keeping Brazil from leaning toward Russia or China.

title: Honda embraces AI, robots at China EV plant to slash staffing
description: Around 30% of the EV assembly process has been automated at the new GAC Honda plant. (Photo by Shizuka Tanabe) Automaker boosts efficiency with eye on 100% electrification goal SHIZUKA TANABE March 27, 2025 00:40 JST GUANGZHOU — Honda Motor is using artificial intelligence and automation to streamline production at a new Chinese electric vehicle plant, cutting staffing needs by 30% compared with its conventional factories. GAC Honda Automobile, Honda’s joint venture with Chinese automaker Guangzhou Automobile Group, opened its EV plant in Guangzhou , which came online late last year, to the media on Wednesday. Production of the P7 electric sport utility vehicle, set to release in April, kicked off that day. Automated guided vehicles (AGVs) were used to move body parts around the factory floor, allowing Honda to eliminate all tasks in which workers transported parts during the pressing process. AGVs were used to transport EV batteries, which weigh about 600 kilograms, as well. Honda also adopted AI-based technology to optimize the welding process for the first time. “We will use electrification as an opportunity to overhaul the way we produce vehicles,” said a GAC Honda executive. “The key is to reduce fixed costs as much as possible.” Automated guided vehicles transport parts at GAC Honda’s Guangzhou plant. (Photo by Shizuka Tanabe) EVs, plug-in hybrids and other new energy vehicles made up 49% of new passenger vehicle sales in China in 2024. “The trend toward electrification in China is clear,” GAC Honda President Katsuhide Moriyama said. But Honda faces headwinds in China. It is expected to suffer a 55 billion yen ($365 million) loss on investments accounted for using the equity method — a metric that reflects the performance of its Chinese operations — for the fiscal year ending Monday. With a relatively limited lineup of new energy vehicles, Honda’s new vehicle sales in China fell roughly 30% in 2024 to 850,000 units. Of them, only around 10,000 were EVs. Artificial intelligence optimizes the amount of current and voltage used in the welding process at the new GAC Honda plant. (Photo by Shizuka Tanabe) This has led to excess capacity. Honda is looking to produce vehicles more efficiently given the competitive market. Honda aims for 100% of its new vehicle sales to come from EVs or fuel-cell vehicles in 2040. Its global EV production is only expected to grow as it plans new releases in North America and Japan. “Knowledge on how to assemble batteries and suspension parts as efficiently as possible can be applied globally,” the GAC Honda executive said.

title: Major Japan regional bank seeks stake in peer as interest rates rise
description: Japan's banks are rushing to bolster their foundations with the country's interest rates finally rising. (Photo by Yutaka Miyaguchi) Chiba Bank would become Chiba Kogyo's top shareholder in $130mn deal RYUTA MINAMIHATA March 27, 2025 00:08 JST TOKYO — Japanese regional lender Chiba Bank is finalizing plans to acquire a nearly 20% stake in peer Chiba Kogyo Bank for an estimated 20 billion yen ($133 million), Nikkei has learned, looking to bolster its foundation as interest rates rise. Chiba Bank, the largest regional bank in Chiba prefecture, just east of Tokyo, will purchase the shares from Ariake Capital, an investment company that targets regional lenders and other entities. Under the share transfer agreement expected soon, Chiba Bank will acquire 19.9% of the shares in Chiba Kogyo, the prefecture’s third largest regional bank, on a voting rights basis. Ariake Capital began making substantial investments in Chiba Kogyo around 2022, providing advice on improving management. It became the largest shareholder in January 2025. Chiba Kogyo’s market capitalization stands around 90 billion yen, making the stake to be acquired by Chiba Bank worth about 18 billion yen. Chiba Bank is expected to become the largest shareholder. Several large regional banks have been able to coexist in Chiba, given the prefecture’s large population and numerous companies stemming from its location in the greater Tokyo metro area. But population decline in southern Chiba has led to consolidation of some branches. With the Bank of Japan moving last year to reverse its longtime negative interest rate policy, and with further rate hikes on the horizon, banks are rushing to solidify their foundations in order to acquire deposits and support business partners. Chiba Kogyo was established in 1952. When Japan’s economic bubble burst, the bank was left with many bad loans and received public funds in 2000. Even after paying off its debt, the lender had to deal with the redemption of preferred shares, which carried a heavy dividend burden. Japan’s Financial Services Agency requires companies that acquire a 20% stake or more of banks and other institutions to obtain authorization for such reasons as ensuring management stability. Chiba Bank and Chiba Kogyo will discuss their future structure and cooperative relationship. Chiba Bank appears to be considering acquiring more than 20% to strengthen the relationship further. As the two banks deepen their relationship, the response of major Japanese lender Mizuho Bank, which holds 12.6% of Chiba Kogyo’s shares, also will be a focus. Mizuho’s predecessor, the former Fuji Bank, took on Chiba Kogyo’s capital increases. Mizuho counted Chiba Kogyo as an equity method affiliate for many years, until 2023.

title: China’s vice premier airs tariff concerns with U.S. trade chief
description: U.S. President Donald Trump is preparing to impose reciprocal tariffs next week, potentially slapping more duties on Chinese goods. © Reuters He Lifeng and USTR Jamieson Greer held 'candid' discussion: Chinese state media March 27, 2025 00:01 JST BEIJING (Reuters) — China’s Vice Premier He Lifeng expressed “solemn concerns” over U.S. tariffs and planned “reciprocal” duties in a video call with U.S. top trade chief Jamieson Greer on Wednesday, Chinese state media Xinhua news agency reported. The two men had a “candid and in-depth” exchange of views on key economic and trade issues , and agreed to maintain communications, Xinhua said. The call came as U.S. President Donald Trump prepares to impose reciprocal tariffs next week, potentially slapping more duties on Chinese goods. Trump has imposed 20% levies on all Chinese imports since taking office in January, accusing Beijing of not doing enough to stem the outflow of chemical precursors used to produce the deadly drug fentanyl. China retaliated by imposing targeted tariffs of up to 15% on some U.S. goods ranging from oil and liquefied natural gas to agricultural products. The tit-for-tat measures added new strains to relations between the two major powers that have already sunk to historic lows in recent years due to issues ranging from trade and technology curbs to Taiwan.

title: BYD to double overseas sales to 800,000 in 2025, chairman says
description: China's BYD, which has overtaken Elon Musk's Tesla in EV sales, will continue building factories overseas without partners as it has abundant funding, Chairman Wang Chuanfu said.  Chinese EV giant to overcome tariffs with local assembly in some countries March 26, 2025 20:58 JST SHANGHAI (Reuters) — Chinese electric vehicle giant BYD aims to double its sales outside China to more than 800,000 cars in 2025 and will look to overcome tariffs by assembling cars locally, its chairman told analysts on an earnings call on Tuesday. BYD, which sold 417,204 units overseas in 2024, expects to see “a substantial rise” in its market share in Britain, which is “very open” to competitive Chinese products, according to a transcript of the call by Wang Chuanfu that was reviewed by Reuters. The company also sees “great opportunities” to grow rapidly in Latin American and Southeast Asian countries, where the governments and people are friendly towards Chinese brands, he said. With governments abroad weighing or levying tariffs against Chinese-made cars, BYD plans to keep its cost advantage by purchasing key components from China and assembling the vehicles in local markets, Wang added, without specifying the countries he was referring to. A BYD representative confirmed the target of doubling overseas sales to 800,000 units this year, but did not respond to a request for comment on the rest of Wang’s remarks. BYD is leading an overseas push by Chinese automakers, opening showrooms in markets from Australia to Germany as it seeks a respite from a brutal price war at home. Wang said last year that BYD expects exports to help shore up profitability. During the Tuesday meeting he told analysts he expected to see the majority of BYD’s profits coming from overseas markets “at a certain stage”. He didn’t specify the timing for that to be achieved. The company will continue building factories overseas without partners as it has abundant funding, Wang added. BYD is currently building a factory in Brazil, its biggest market outside China, although the development was hit last year by allegations of labour abuses. The carmaker is also building factories in Thailand, Hungary and Turkey. In addition, Wang said that BYD had no plans to sell into Canada and the United States in the short term due to geopolitical developments. The Trump administration has maintained duties of 100% on Chinese-made EVs, as has Canada. Wang told the analysts he was confident BYD’s profitability per vehicle would exceed Toyota’s when it reached the scale of the Japanese manufacturer, saying BYD’s cost control was better. Toyota 7203.T, the world’s top automaker by sales, sold 10.8 million vehicles in 2024, while BYD sold 4.27 million. BYD, which is targeting sales of 5.5 million units this year, has roiled the Chinese auto market by rolling out more affordable models, including its entry-level Seagull electric hatchback that sells for less than $10,000. It also offers smart driving features at no extra charge on most of its lineup. BYD plans to expand the team that works on intelligent software and components such as semiconductors to as many as 8,000 people from the current 5,000, Wang said, without giving a timeline. It also intends to take its affordable smart driving technologies to the global market in 2026 or 2027 and plans to send more employees overseas to handle the plan, he added.

title: Rupiah decline different from 1998 crisis, says Indonesia central bank
description: Bank Indonesia held a press briefing on March 26, after the central bank, lenders and investors saw a rapid fall of the rupiah in the currency market the day before. (Photo by Ken Kobayashi) Bank Indonesia assures drop in rupiah will not lead to repeat of past crises ISMI DAMAYANTI ISMI DAMAYANTI March 26, 2025 20:52 JST JAKARTA — Indonesia’s central bank on Wednesday tried to tame market concerns over the rupiah’s recent depreciation to a 27-year low, saying the situation is far from a repeat of the 1998 financial crisis. “We’ve learned a lot since then,” said Solikin Juhro, Bank Indonesia’s head of macroprudential policy, during a press briefing after the central bank, lenders and investors saw a rapid fall of the rupiah in the currency market on Tuesday. “We don’t need to worry too much about this because this is far from the situation in 1998 with weakening purchasing power, yet a different situation,” said Bank Indonesia spokesperson Ramdan Denny Prakoso in the briefing, echoing the macroprudential policy head. After hitting a low of 16,640 per dollar on the previous day, the weakest since June 1998 , the rupiah rebounded slightly to 16,588 on Wednesday, based on Bank Indonesia’s Jakarta Interbank Spot Dollar Rate (JISDOR). In 1998, the rupiah plunged from 2,800 to 16,800 per U.S. dollar amid a lack of financial market resilience and limited foreign exchange reserves. “At that time, our financial system was far more vulnerable,” Juhro said. He pointed to Indonesia’s stability during the 2008 global financial crisis as proof of progress. “We now have stronger regulations and comprehensive policy frameworks in place.” “The banking sector now has been mitigated from crisis [with an] integrated prevention protocol that we developed,” Juhro added. “Macroprudential policy aims to ensure optimal credit growth, a resilient financial system, and inclusive financing, all of which support sustainable economic growth.” Coordinating Economic Minister Airlangga Hartarto expressed confidence that the rupiah will rebound, supported by strong economic fundamentals, including solid export performance and healthy foreign exchange reserves in the medium to long term. “We also have regulations in place to retain export earnings within the country,” he said. Hartarto emphasized that these export earnings will serve as a key foundation for the rupiah’s stability. “With these fundamentals, we won’t remain under pressure for long.” The recent rupiah weakening came from a combination of factors such as a widening current account deficit amid export uncertainties due to U.S. President Donald Trump’s trade policy, early concerns over fiscal deficit, and uncertainty surrounding the initial phase of Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto’s administration. The underwhelming market response to the launch of the Danantara sovereign wealth fund and rumors of Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati’s potential resignation next month also hurt the currency’s value. Teuku Riefky, macroeconomics and financial market researcher at the Institute for Economics and Social Research at the University of Indonesia, said domestic sentiment has also affected the rupiah’s decline. “Capital outflows have been driven in part by domestic factors, including political tensions with rising demonstrations in the public,” said Riefky. A wave of mass demonstrations has erupted in several cities across Indonesia over the past week, driven largely by concerns over the legalized involvement of military personnel in civilian roles. Activists and civilian groups have called the policy a setback for democratic progress. To stabilize the currency, Bank Indonesia has intervened in multiple mechanisms, including the spot currency market, the domestic non-deliverable forward market, and the government bond market. The central bank will maintain rupiah stability in line with market mechanisms and the country’s economic fundamentals, according to Juhro. “Comparing with other currencies like the Japanese yen or Korean won, they’re not on a brink of crisis [because] their fundamentals remain resilient.” Juhro also noted that corporate performance remains robust with strong financial capacity, a sign of underlying economic strength. “This helps keep household risks in check and incomes remain within a relatively safe zone.” The stock market had a breather on Wednesday, with the benchmark Jakarta Composite Index rising 3.8% compared with Tuesday’s close. Additional reporting by Rezha Hadyan.

title: China demand slump hits earnings at top consumer goods companies
description: Consumers in China are reining in spending, dragging down earnings at some consumer goods companies. © Reuters Food, household goods makers looking for overseas growth face price-dumping claims WATARU SUZUKI March 26, 2025 20:19 JST HONG KONG — China’s top food and household product companies said they would step up efforts to seek growth overseas after weak demand at home dented earnings last year. Hengan International Group, a major producer of tissues and disposable diapers, reported on Tuesday that net profit fell 18% from a year ago to 2.3 billion yuan ($317 million) in 2024. “We’ll be looking for more opportunities overseas,” Hengan International Group CEO Hui Ching Lau told reporters on Tuesday. Lau said the company will be “promoting the development of overseas business as an important strategy this year more than before,” although he did not specify targets. Lau noted that “competition is extremely fierce” in China and the company is suffering the impact of a price war between e-commerce operators such as Pinduoduo and Douyin. For example, Hengan’s 24-box tissue pack is sold for just 33 yuan on Pinduoduo compared to 62 on Taobao, which is owned by Alibaba Group. Higher raw material prices and increased spending on promotions also eroded Hengan’s profit margin. “If everyone were to operate at a loss continuously, a company wouldn’t be able to keep going,” said Lau, projecting that such a trend would persist until the market undergoes consolidation. He added that China’s tissue market remains extremely fragmented, pointing to the “several hundred” small factories operating in just the one city of Baoding, in northeastern Hebei province. Meanwhile, bottled water maker Nongfu Spring’s annual revenue and net profit grew less than 1%, dragged down by a slump in the second half of the year. In particular, its packaged water business took a sharp hit, falling 21% from a year ago to 15.95 billion yuan. The company blamed the decline on “a surge of online attacks and malicious defamation” since February last year after Chinese nationalists hurled accusations at its red-capped water bottles for resembling the Japanese flag when held up against a piece of white paper. The company later introduced a new bottle with a green cap. Hengan International Group CEO Hui Ching Lau, middle, expects China’s tissue and disposable diaper market to consolidate in the near future due to “fierce competition.” (Photo by Wataru Suzuki) Separately, founder Zhong Shanshan also criticized the cutthroat price competition among online marketplace players, reportedly describing the pressure piled on sellers as “bad money driving out the good.” In an earnings report released on Tuesday, Zhong said the company will “actively seek market development opportunities overseas.” Nongfu generates nearly all of its revenue from mainland China. Results at both Hengan and Nongfu missed analyst estimates published on FactSet. China faces deflationary pressures on the back of a property market downturn and as consumers reined in spending due to weak job prospects. The consumer price index for the first two months of 2025 slipped 0.1% annually, bogged down by declines in food and consumer goods prices. Given weak demand at home, some companies are expanding abroad but such moves have led to accusations by other countries, including the U.S., that China was dumping excess capacity overseas. Premier Li Qiang has acknowledged the issue, saying in a government work report released earlier this month that China will “take comprehensive steps to address rat race competition.” WH Group Chairman Wan Long, right, told reporters in Hong Kong on Tuesday that the U.S.-China tariff war will “not have a significant impact” on the meat processing company. (Photo by Wataru Suzuki) Other companies that have a presence overseas fared better. The world’s largest pork producer WH Group, said stronger earnings in Europe and the U.S. helped offset lower packaged meat and pork sales in China. WH Group reported an 8% decline in packaged meat sales in China, which it attributed to a “lack of effective demand from the market.” Sales in Europe, however, grew by 25%, thanks to its acquisition of Spanish meat producer Argal which was completed in March 2024. In January, WH Group listed its U.S. meat processing subsidiary Smithfield on the Nasdaq exchange. Chairman and CEO Wan Long said the company would “continue to accelerate expansion in the U.S. and Europe” through acquisitions and would not be as active in China. When asked about the impact of the intensifying trade war between the U.S. and China, Wan said the additional tariffs would “not have a significant impact” on its business due to resilient demand in the U.S. and the group’s global footprint. WH Group said it would adjust its product mix to minimize the impact. On a positive note, higher spending for collectible toys propelled Pop Mart’s net profit by 189% annually to 3.1 billion yuan. Known for its animated characters made of vinyl, the group’s revenue in mainland China grew 52%, while overseas sales jumped nearly fivefold. Pop Mart CEO Wang Ning said during an analyst meeting on Wednesday that the company aims to increase its total revenue by 50% in 2025. Part of the strategy is to raise the ratio of its overseas revenue from 39% in 2024 to over 50%. He added that domestic performance in the first quarter has “exceeded our expectations,” thanks to hugely popular figurines from blockbuster movie Nezha 2. The company’s Hong Kong-listed shares climbed over 11% after his remarks.

title: Annual Thai censure debate centers on Thaksin Shinawatra’s political role
description: Thai opposition leader and People's Party leader Natthaphong Ruengpanyawut speaks during the annual parliamentary no-confidence debate. © Reuters Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra easily survives no-confidence vote FRANCESCA REGALADO March 26, 2025 19:49 JST BANGKOK — Thailand’s main opposition People’s Party used a two-day parliamentary censure debate to question Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra about her father Thaksin Shinawatra’s influence on the government. The prime minister easily survived a no-confidence vote on Wednesday, 319-162, but the debate allowed the opposition to air in the legislature allegations that have dogged Paetongtarn over her seven-month tenure. Opposition leader Nattaphong Ruengpanyawut said Paetongtarn “lacks the qualifications” to serve as prime minister. “She evades taxes, evades her duties, and evades reality. Therefore, she cannot be trusted to continue as prime minister,” he said in his closing remarks late Tuesday. The censure debate is an annual ritual for the Thai prime minister. A political novice at 38, Paetongtarn’s election in August came after the Constitutional Court removed then-Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin. Paetongtarn was quickly selected by her Pheu Thai party’s ruling coalition, a mashup of conservative parties that previously opposed her father Thaksin. Thaksin was deposed as prime minister by a military coup in 2006, with the court dissolving his Thai Rak Thai party. His self-exile abroad ended in 2022, the day of Srettha’s election. “Twenty years ago, Thailand lost everything to get Thaksin out of the country,” Nattaphong said, referring to the coup. “But 20 years later, Thailand is about to lose everything again to get Thaksin back,” he added, a nod to how Pheu Thai achieved power. Pheu Thai was beaten in the May 2023 general election by the progressive Move Forward Party, the predecessor of the People’s Party. The two groups initially planned to form a government, until Pheu Thai joined forces with its conservative former rivals. Paetongtarn stood by her close relationship with Thaksin. “It is not a bad thing for me to listen to or use or consider Dr. Thaksin’s advice because he is a person with knowledge and ability and is widely accepted both domestically and internationally,” she said in her closing remarks. Other opposition parliamentarians questioned Thaksin’s confinement in the Police General Hospital, where he served six months of a one-year commuted sentence before receiving a royal pardon. A surprise intervention was made by former Deputy Prime Minister Prawit Wongsuwan. He used his first speech in parliament to criticize Pheu Thai’s plan to legalize gambling. Prawit, one of the generals that led a coup against then-Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra — Paetongtarn’s aunt — in 2014, split from the Pheu Thai coalition last year. “Casinos will lead the country to the most dangerous disaster because it will weaken society and create many more gray businesses,” Prawit said. The cabinet plans to submit its draft bill on so-called entertainment complexes, which include casinos, to parliament despite questions of their legality. On Wednesday, Nattaphong exchanged pleasantries with Paetongtarn on the dais after the vote. Much like Paetongtarn, Nattaphong rose to the top of his party after a Constitutional Court ruling that dissolved the Move Forward Party. The opposition’s senior leaders were also banned from politics for 10 years. During the debate, Paetongtarn accused Nattaphong in turn of being influenced by another unelected official, alluding to progressive firebrand Thanathorn Juangroongruangkit. Thanathorn was banned from politics for 10 years in 2020. “If the party before mine had not been politically persecuted, today we might still have a prime minister named Thaksin, and your party might have a leader named Thanathorn,” Paetongtarn said. In rebuttal, Nattaphong pressed the prime minister to act on her party’s promise to reform the constitution. Nattaphong told Nikkei Asia last year that the constitution, instituted in 2017 by the leaders of the 2014 military coup, skews the electoral process and gives the court outsize power to dissolve political parties. The debate also yielded a promise from Paetongtarn to pay taxes on share transfers. People’s Party MP Wiroj Lakkhanaadisorn revealed on Monday that Paetongtarn had not paid taxes on share transfers for nine years, accruing a bill of 218 million baht ($6.4 million). Analysts expect a cabinet reshuffle now that the no-confidence vote has passed. The reshuffle will likely be limited to the ministries controlled by Pheu Thai with coalition partners holding on to their portfolios. Additional reporting by Anchalee Romruen and Niyakarn Atiyudhakul

title: Nissan incoming CEO Espinosa has ‘no taboos’ on partnerships
description: Ivan Espinosa, Nissan's incoming president and CEO, speaks to reporters at a media roundtable held at the carmaker’s technical center near Tokyo on March 25. (Photo by Sayumi Take) Carmaker seeks to revamp corporate culture and speed up product development SAYUMI TAKE SAYUMI TAKE March 26, 2025 18:33 JST TOKYO — Nissan Motor will have “no taboos” when it comes to exploring partnerships to enhance its competitiveness, according to Ivan Espinosa, who is preparing to become president and CEO of the struggling carmaker next week. Nissan is seeking partners that can push it into “the next era of technology”, said Espinosa, currently Nissan’s chief planning officer, at a media roundtable on Tuesday. “In the next 10 years, we need to really, really focus on developing our own ability to deliver and develop the intelligent car,” he said, referring to the use of artificial intelligence and other technologies to enhance the driving experience and autonomous features. He hinted at an openness to partnerships not limited to traditional carmakers whom he said lacked some high-level traits and competencies.
