Teaming up with such insiders could unlock synergies and spread costs in sales, powertrain technology and battery investment, “But there’s another [part] happening, which is, who should you partner with in order to develop this intelligent car in the future?” Espinosa will take the helm of the ailing company less than two months after it abandoned merger talks with Honda Motor , a plan many investors saw as a potential long-term solution to its weakening competitiveness. Nissan said it is still committed to collaborating on electrification and auto software technologies with its Japanese rival. “The first thing that came through my mind [when offered the job] is, a CEO is normally dealing with one or two major crises in his or her career … but I have to deal with four or five,” said the 46-year-old Mexican national who was appointed to be the next leader of the company earlier this month. Espinosa highlighted the need to address “a deep morale   crisis” within the company, along with implementing turnaround measures initially announced under his predecessor, Makoto Uchida, who will step down at the end of this month. “We are, at the moment, lacking empathy at Nissan,” he said. “It’s kind of human nature … It’s very easy to start finger-pointing at each other” when business is difficult, he said. “Some of the messages that I’ve exchanged one on one with new executive committee members is the need to work as one single team,” said Espinosa. “We need to work together, hand in hand … with one single direction, so we can be quick, we can be determined, no more hesitation about what we should be doing.” Nissan must also speed up decision-making and product launches. For example, the carmaker currently takes about 55 months to develop a new car but will aim to shorten that time to about 37 months or less, he said. Espinosa, who joined Nissan in 2003 and currently serves on Nissan’s executive committee, admitted to “regret” over not pushing earlier for cultural and other internal changes. “Changing a big company like Nissan is not easy … [but] I’m determined to do that change. Now I have the ability to do so, [and] I have very clear in my mind what has to change.” A pressing issue for Nissan is generating revenue. It expects a net loss of 80 billion yen  ($532 million) for the fiscal year ending this month, taking it into the red for the first time in four years. Major credit rating agencies have downgraded Nissan’s credit to junk status with a negative outlook. The company will update its product lineup in key markets, including the U.S., where it is struggling with declining sales. For the fiscal year starting in April, it will launch a plug-in hybrid model of the Rogue sports utility vehicle in the country to address the absence of hybrids, an increasingly popular vehicle type. Nissan is also developing a new generation model of its hybrid e-Power system, seeking to enhance fuel efficiency when the car is traveling at high speed by up to 15% versus the current system. The updated technology will reach American consumers in fiscal 2026 via a new model Rogue. Nissan is developing a new version of the Leaf, its flagship EV. (Nissan Motor) On electric vehicles, the company is developing a new version of the flagship Leaf, with improved aerodynamics, energy management and driving range. It will launch the new model in the U.S. in fiscal 2025 compatible with Tesla’s North American Charging Standard (NACS), a first for a Nissan EV. Espinosa also hopes to address Nissan’s weak brand power, which has also been blamed for the company’s poor business performance. “My vision for the portfolio, moving forward, is to have maybe five or six brand-oriented models that should go to as [close to] every market as possible  … cars that are really describing what Nissan is about,” he told reporters. Models like the Patrol SUV, the Z sports car and the Leaf, can help customers understand that “Nissan is excitement, Nissan is technology,” said Espinosa, a longtime product specialist.

title: Vietnam approves Starlink service in 5-year pilot plan
description: On a clear moonlit evening, SpaceX's Falcon 9 launched Starlink 12-21 internet satellites, in Florida on March 12. Starlink is slated to serve up to 600,000 accounts in Vietnam after a pilot project was agreed to with the government. © AP Elon Musk's tech company can provide up to 600,000 subscriptions nationwide MAI NGUYEN March 26, 2025 18:11 JST HANOI — The Vietnamese government has given the green light for U.S. billionaire Elon Musk’s SpaceX to launch its Starlink satellite internet service in a five-year pilot program, it said on Wednesday. Starlink can provide its service to a maximum of 600,000 subscriptions in Vietnam, and the pilot program must end before Jan. 1, 2031, the government said in a statement on its website. There will be no limit on foreign ownership of Starlink service in Vietnam. However, the project still needs to ensure national defense and security. The government has assigned the Ministry of National Defense, the Ministry of Public Security to coordinate and the Ministry of Science and Technology to jointly work on the project. Vietnam’s moves come just a week ahead of U.S. President Donald Trump’s expected announcement on reciprocal tariffs on April 2 that could apply to all U.S. trading partners, but he said on Monday that he “may give a lot of countries breaks.” Vietnam has been trying to reduce its trade deficit with the U.S., which was $123.5 billion last year and the third biggest trade gap for the U.S. after China and Mexico. Its finance ministry announced Tuesday that Vietnam is planning to cut import tariffs on several U.S. products, including liquefied natural gas, cars, ethanol and other agriculture products. Vietnam’s economic growth of 7.1% in 2024 was one of the strongest in the region, but it is highly reliant on exports, which grew 14% last year, and the U.S. was its biggest market. Last week, Vietnam’s Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh greeted a representative of conglomerate The Trump Organization in Vietnam. The company is planning to invest around $1.5 billion in an urban complex project that includes a golf course in northern Hung Yen province , according to a report on the prime minister’s website. The Starlink services that will be allowed include fixed satellite services (internet access services and privately leased channel services for mobile receiving and transmitting stations) and mobile satellite services (internet access services at sea and on airplanes), the Vietnamese government statement said. The country’s remote areas still have limited access to the internet due to the high cost of infrastructure investment, so low-earth orbit systems such as Starlink can “act as a complementary solution to provide telecommunication and internet services with many advantages,” Vietnam’s Authority of Radio Frequency Management said on its website earlier this month. Vietnam’s approval of Starlink also aligns with its efforts to boost its digital transformation and attract more foreign investments, especially in high-tech sectors such as AI and semiconductors. Vietnam has urged foreign investors to boost their investments and involve local companies in their supply chains. Samsung has invested more than $20 billion in Vietnam, and Nvidia is opening an R&D center in the country. The Starlink pilot plan may be canceled at any time if the license is withdrawn or the project violates the requirements stated by the authorities. Last week, the Italian defense minister said negotiations on a potential contract between Starlink and the Italian government have stalled, which reflected broader geopolitical tensions, Reuters reported.

title: Jollibee group to reach 10,000 eateries around the world in 2025
description: A Jollibee employee prepares a takeaway order at a Manila store. Jollibee expects its store network to grow as much as 8% in 2025. © Reuters Philippine food giant shifts to franchising to speed up North America expansion RAMON ROYANDOYAN RAMON ROYANDOYAN March 26, 2025 17:24 JST MANILA — The number of Jollibee Foods’ group restaurants is set to surpass 10,000 this year as the conglomerate moves to a franchising strategy in North America to speed up expansion. At the end of last year, the Philippine restaurant group had 9,766 outlets worldwide, including those of its flagship fried chicken Jollibee chain. This year, the company will invest from 18 billion pesos to 21 billion pesos ($312 million to $364 million) for 700 to 800 new stores, which would bring its total network above 10,000 outlets. “We’re not in all 50 states [in the U.S.]. We’re in only maybe 15 states,” Richard Shin, the company’s chief financial and risk officer, told reporters on Tuesday while briefing them on last year’s earnings, referring to its North American expansion strategy. The Jollibee chain opened its first North American store in Daly City, California, in 1998. At the end of 2024, it had 103 locations in the U.S. and Canada. In addition, the company had 266 North American restaurants under other brands. To accelerate the expansion, Jollibee will expand the franchising of its brands in the U.S., according to the company. Franchisees will be able to locate eateries in stand-alone buildings, strip malls, airports or transit hubs. “Our growth model for capital, again, is shifting to the franchise model,” Shin said. “We’ll have less and less capex [capital expenditure] requirements for store expansions.” Shin said Jollibee sees an opportunity in a North American market where Kentucky Fried Chicken, he noted, has 8,000 locations. “So you could imagine the room for growth for a brand like Jollibee,” he said, “which consistently gets voted by consumers two years in a row, 2023 and 2024, as the best fried chicken.” For the flagship fried chicken chain, “Jollibee’s projected expansion goal is to have 350 stores across both the U.S. and Canada in the next couple of years,” the company said earlier this month in a news statement when it announced a new franchising partnership in the U.S. The company’s net profit for 2024 grew 17.7% to 10.3 billion pesos, anchored by a double-digit revenue increase driven by store expansions, including acquisitions. In its earnings guidance, Jollibee indicated it expects 8% to 12% growth this year in “system wide sales” — all sales to consumers by company-owned and franchised stores. Jollibee also indicated it is shooting for its store network to grow as much as 8%. The food giant has been aggressive in acquiring brands , scooping up South Korean chain Compose Coffee in August, taking full ownership of Hong Kong-based restaurant chain Tim Ho Wan and acquiring Taiwanese wellness soup brand Moon Moon. Jollibee also has ownership stakes in Chinese fast-food chain Yonghe King, and American brands Smashburger and The Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf. Additional reporting by Ella Hermonio.

title: South Korea’s Lee Jae-myung found not guilty of breaking election law
description: Lee Jae-myung, leader of South Korea's main opposition Democratic Party, arrives at a court in Seoul, on March 26.  © Reuters If upheld, ruling would pave the way for opposition leader to run in next election STEVEN BOROWIEC March 26, 2025 15:57 JST Updated on March 26, 2025 17:19 JST SEOUL — A South Korean court on Wednesday overturned a lower court’s ruling and found the leader of the main opposition political party not guilty of violating election law — a verdict that if upheld would clear the way for him to run in the next presidential election. The prosecutors can appeal the ruling, which would bring the case to the Supreme Court, South Korea’s highest legal body. Speaking outside the court after the decision was announced, Lee Jae-myung thanked the court for what he called a “proper ruling.” The charges against Lee stem from remarks he made while running in his party’s presidential primary in 2021 when he claimed to have been unacquainted with a key figure in a property development scandal. The scandal involved a redevelopment project in the city of Seongnam, where Lee was mayor. Prosecutors argue that Lee was lying about his relationship with businessman Kim Moon-ki to hide his own culpability in the property deal. Immediately after the court’s decision was announced, Kweon Seong-dong, the leader of the ruling People Power Party, called verdict “regretful” and urged the Supreme Court to quickly rule on the case.  Lee, a lawyer by training and veteran politician, lost the 2022 presidential election to now-impeached President Yoon Suk Yeol by the narrowest margin in South Korea’s democratic history. A protester in Seoul holds a sign calling for opposition leader Lee Jae-myung to be arrested on Dec. 31, 2024.   © Reuters Yoon, a bitter rival of Lee’s, is awaiting a Constitutional Court verdict on his December impeachment on charges of leading an insurrection. Lawmakers voted to impeach Yoon following his attempt in early December to institute martial law, a measure he claimed was necessary to protect South Korea from “anti-state forces” in the opposition. The measure was quickly voted down in the National Assembly, but the attempt sparked a political crisis that is still unfolding months later. The Constitutional Court concluded hearings on Yoon’s case late last month and is expected to render its verdict within days, although no official date has been announced. If the court finds Yoon not guilty, he will be immediately restored to office. If it finds him guilty, a snap election will take place within 60 days. Data released last week by pollster Gallup Korea showed Lee to be the leading choice among candidates that could run in the next presidential election. Lee had 36% of support, far ahead of the No. 2 prospective contender, conservative Labor Minister Kim Moon-soo .

title: Ditching net zero is a dangerous gamble for Japan’s megabanks
description: MUFG and SMBC must reaffirm their net-zero commitments and translate these pledges into actionable policies and targets aligned with climate science and the Paris Agreement. (Source photos by Yuki Nakao) MUFG and SMBC's UN climate exit signals a troubling retreat from sustainability Eri Watanabe Eri Watanabe March 26, 2025 17:05 JST Eri Watanabe is a senior Japan energy finance campaigner at Market Forces, a clean energy finance advocacy group working across Asia and Australia. Japan’s two largest banks, MUFG and SMBC, recently followed the biggest U.S. and Canadian banks in withdrawing from the United Nations-led Net-Zero Banking Alliance. These moves put global banking and investor climate initiatives under threat and place secure economies at risk. Japan’s major banks have a duty to hold firm on their net-zero commitments and accelerate efforts to minimize climate risk. The NZBA is rallying its 130 member banks, which hold $49 trillion in assets, to stay the course. Most of Asia’s banks, including those in Singapore and Malaysia, Japan’s Mizuho and Australia’s biggest four this year have held firm on their commitments to achieving net zero and retaining their NZBA membership. It’s critical that Asia’s banks avoid short-term political and financial expediency, which risks undermining their long-standing commitments to climate goals and sustainability. The transition to a net-zero economy is supercharging, and banks need to recognize that there is no turning back. To avoid losing more members, the NZBA is giving serious consideration to watering down its climate ambitions. Yet for many banks, including those jumping ship, the NZBA has enabled them to engage in greenwashing and window dressing by failing to hold coal, oil and gas companies as well as other high emitting customers to account. MUFG joined NZBA in June 2021 as the first member bank from Japan , and led the alliance’s steering group. In MUFG’s 2024-2026 management plan, the bank pledges to “drive social and environmental progress,” including “achievement of a carbon neutral society.” SMBC has long positioned itself as a green bank and in its 2023-2025 medium-term management plan highlighted its commitment to decarbonization and addressing global inequalities. However, alongside these commitments, MUFG and SMBC have funded oil and gas developments, joining the “dirty dozen” top 12-ranked global financiers of fossil fuels, according to a Banking on Climate Chaos report. The next litmus test for MUFG, SMBC and Mizuho will be whether they can effectively implement measures to support the genuine transition of high-emitting customers. Leading banks in Europe and Australia have demonstrated that financing companies with credible transition plans is core to managing climate and associated financial risks. Last year around one in four investors and shareholders called on Japan’s megabanks to improve disclosure on their assessments of the climate transition plans of their customers. Fortunately, the U.S.-led revolt against corporate environmental, social and governance (ESG) responsibilities has not yet imposed a significant impact on Asian economies. But the risk of a broader shock looms as MUFG, SMBC, Nomura and Norinchukin have jumped on the bandwagon, shunning climate science. People walk through water at a flooded area affected by rising sea levels and land subsidence in North Jakarta, Indonesia, on Nov. 20, 2024.    © Reuters If Japan’s banks fail to adhere to their net-zero commitments and continue supporting companies expanding oil, gas and coal businesses, they jeopardize their bottom lines, their reputations and send damaging signals to the markets they wish to serve. There is overwhelming evidence of immense economic risks associated with climate change. In 25 years, extreme heat, rain and flooding will cause $38 trillion in annual damages, according to the Potsdam Institute. The warning bells must be ringing loud and clear for Japanese banks. A global network of 141 central banks and regulators recently estimated that under current climate targets and policies, the Japanese economy could lose about $9.2 trillion by 2050. Conversely, if private and government leaders unite around the world to fully implement a transition to net-zero emissions by mid-century, by 2070 the global economy could win a $43 trillion windfall and 3.8% more economic growth, according to Deloitte research. Fossil fuels are like a sinking ship. Renewable energy including wind and solar are already undercutting new coal and gas plants on production costs almost everywhere in the world. The economics of coal, oil and gas expansion don’t stack up and more investors are recognizing this cold hard truth. In light of the mounting evidence and dire warnings, the financial sector must not shy away from its role as a catalyst for change and genuinely enable the transition to a net-zero economy. Despite withdrawing from the NZBA, MUFG, SMBC, Nomura and Norinchukin must reaffirm their net-zero commitments and translate these pledges into actionable policies and targets aligned with climate science and the Paris Agreement. Another test for the Japanese megabanks is whether they will continue providing finance for one of the biggest and most polluting liquified natural gas projects ever planned, Papua LNG. MUFG has acted as a financial advisor, yet the Papua New Guinea project faces severe financial, political and legal risks. So far, the Asian Development Bank, France’s biggest bank BNP Paribas, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and 10 other lenders have confirmed they will not lend to Papua LNG. Concerns extend beyond this project, especially as all three Japanese megabanks stand out among the top 10 global banks for their financing of LNG projects. Proponents of LNG have long touted the gas as a cleaner fuel compared to coal. Yet exported LNG emits 33% more greenhouse gases than coal when taking into account transport and polluting methane emissions according to findings published in Energy Science and Engineering. Japan’s obsession with LNG threatens its energy security and economic viability due to a big surplus and decreasing demand. A push to resell excess LNG imports and construct LNG power plants across Asia risks locking developing nations into a costly fossil fuel-dependent future, undermining the shift to affordable renewable energy and worsening climate change impacts. The onus is on Japan’s megabanks to determine their role in the transition to a sustainable economy. The banks’ future viability depends on their commitment to corporate responsibility and sustainable practices, which will dictate their long-term financial success in an evolving global economy and a warming planet.

title: Carmakers focus on hybrids as Thai EV market struggles
description: BYD's first hybrid pickup truck in Thailand, the Shark 6, is displayed at the motor show. (Photo by Yuki Kohara)  Bangkok auto show sees more than 50 brands on display APORNRATH PHOONPHONGPHIPHAT APORNRATH PHOONPHONGPHIPHAT March 26, 2025 15:24 JST Updated on March 26, 2025 16:27 JST BANGKOK — The 46th Bangkok International Motor Show opened to the public on Wednesday, with more than 50 brands from around the world participating and the offerings on display focusing more on hybrid models rather than EVs. As has been the case in recent years, Chinese manufacturers are taking center stage at the event. EV giant BYD unveiled its latest plug-in hybrid pickup truck, the Shark 6 DMO, a four-wheel drive vehicle priced at 1.69 million baht ($49,000). It is BYD’s first HV pickup truck for sale in the kingdom. The company also introduced another plug-in hybrid, the Sealion 6, a large SUV priced at 899,900 baht. “All the new models that BYD launched today will be one of the highlights of this motor show and will also play a key role in driving the Thai auto market forward,” said Pratarnwong Phornprapha, CEO of Rever Automotive, which handles BYD’s sales and distribution in Thailand. SAIC Motor, which operates the MG brand, is launching both premium hybrid and EV models in a bid to appeal to all customer bases. One offering is the all-new MG3 hybrid plus, a fuel-saving sports sedan priced at just 579,900 baht. The Bangkok International Motor Show runs through April 6. (Photo by Yuki Kohara) Great Wall Motor, meanwhile, is showcasing large SUV models, with its hybrid version priced at 929,000 baht and plug-in hybrid at 1.049 million baht. Japan’s carmakers, which had a 70% share of the Thai market in 2024, are also focusing on hybrids. Toyota Motor is promoting seven hybrid models at the show, including versions of its Camry, Yaris and Corolla brands as well as for its luxury brands such as the Alphard and Vellfire. GWM Vehicle is displayed during Bangkok International Motor Show on March 24. (Photo by Yuki Kohara) “Hybrid models find a good market [in Thailand],” said Nutthorn Sinives, vice president (National Marketing) of Toyota Motor Thailand. “Although many people switched to EVs, certain groups prefer hybrids.” Another key Japanese player, Mitsubishi Motors, launched its XForce HEV hybrid model at the show, with carries a price tag ranging from 899,000 baht to 1.089 million baht. Hybrid sales in Thailand rose to 117,789 units in 2024, up 26% from 2023. Consumer demand is also growing for plug-in hybrids, which can be charged from a standard power outlet, with sales in the kingdom totaling 1,753 units in the first two months of this year, up 478% compared with the same period last year. In contrast, demand for EVs fell as oversupply has triggered a price war, leading people to hold back on purchases in hopes that manufacturers will cut prices in the future. Toyota Motor is promoting seven hybrid models at the show, including versions of its Camry, Yaris and Corolla brands. (Photo by Yuki Kohara)  Sales of EVs came to 66,732 units in 2024, down 9.2% from the previous year. EV demand in the first two months of this year remained flat as sales fell 0.12% compared with the same period last year to 14,558 units. High household debt has seen banks apply more stringent loan assessments of late, making it harder for Thais to buy new cars. Thailand’s auto industry saw total car sales drop 26% to 572,675 units for the whole of 2024. This trend has continued into 2025, as total car sales for January and February dropped 9.53% compared with the same period of 2024, to 97,395 units, according to the Federation of Thai Industries (FTI). “We need to wait and see how many cars can be sold during the International Motor Show,” which runs from March 26 to April 6, said Surapong Paisitpattanapong, spokesperson for the FTI’s automotive industry club. Thailand’s total car production is also down, dropping 13.62% on the year to 115,487 units in February, while production in the first two months of 2025 dropped 19.29% to 222,590 units. “Considering factors such as driving range, charging time, spare parts prices, charging time and after-sales service, I think hybrids offer more flexibility than EVs,” Mek Srilomsak, a 34-year-old assistant professor at King Mongkut’s Institute of Technology Ladkrabang, told Nikkei Asia. “In addition, considering Thailand’s industrial sector, which includes many OEMs (original equipment manufacturing) for internal combustion engine parts, promoting hybrids could be a good compromise that benefits both consumers and the industry.”

title: Pakistan’s dispute over new canal project threatens political coalition
description: Fishermen cast their nets into the Indus River in Pakistan on March 15.  © Reuters Experts say $750m project is impractical and unsustainable Adnan Aamir ADNAN AAMIR March 26, 2025 14:15 JST ISLAMABAD — Growing concerns over a potential water crisis from the building of a new canal have sparked opposition across Pakistan’s southern province of Sindh, with the local assembly passing a resolution against it in mid-March. This has raised fear that the Pakistan People’s Party (PPP), which has Sindh as its stronghold, could leave the governing coalition of Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif over the issue. In February, the federal government launched an ambitious agriculture project, the Green Pakistan Initiative, to enhance food security through corporate farming, with the Pakistan army taking the lead. Under this initiative, six canals will be constructed, including one in the Cholistan desert. The government will invest $750 million to build the 176-kilometer-long canal to irrigate 1.2 million acres of barren lands in the desert within the Punjab province. The government claims that the Cholistan canal will use flood water for four months a year and river water from Punjab in the remaining months. River water flows downstream from the north in Punjab to Sindh province in the south. However, on March 13, the Sindh provincial assembly passed a resolution against the construction of this canal. Politicians and rights activists in Sindh allege that the new canal will ultimately eat up the share of water in their province, which was determined by the Water Apportionment Accord of 1991, an agreement between the provinces of the country. If less water flows from the Indus River into the Arabian Sea, there would likely be a big impact on the Indus River Delta, which is home to over a million people, animals and mangrove forests, said water rights activists. “Diverting more river flows away from the delta will hasten land erosion, which has significant environmental consequences as well as implications for migration from areas with rising tides coming in,” Erum Sattar, a lecturer who researches the Indus at Tufts University in the U.S., told Nikkei Asia. Shahab Usto, a civil rights lawyer based in Karachi, warns that water availability could decrease by 30% to 40% in the coming years. “In Sindh, where 70% of the economy depends on agriculture, the [new canal] project threatens livelihoods and can fuel unrest,” he said. “If this canal is built forcefully, without consensus, it could even push the country toward internal conflict.” Experts said that the plan to build a new canal to irrigate a barren desert is impractical and completely unsustainable. “ Punjab [government] insists that the Cholistan canal will function as a flood canal, but floods are unreliable. Since 2010, the Indus River system has not experienced any major floods,” Naseer Memon, a climate change consultant, told Nikkei. “In such a situation, with a huge water deficit already existing, there is simply no surplus water available to support large-scale corporate farming projects,” he added. A farmer sprays pesticide in a field near the Indus River in Pakistan. The Indus River Delta is home to over a million people, animals and mangrove forests.   © Reuters Usto, the water rights lawyer, said that all hydrologists have opposed this canal project because it’s neither viable nor sustainable. “Even India’s Indira Gandhi Canal, just across the border from Pakistan’s Cholistan, failed under similar circumstances,” he said. There is also a question about the $750 million cost of this new canal project. “Given the government’s track record of not completing projects on time, alongside frequent time and cost overruns, the reliability of these cost estimates is highly questionable,” Hassan Abbas, a water expert based in Islamabad, told Nikkei. Rights activists in Sindh argue that the federal government initiated the canal project without seeking approval from Council of Common Interests (CCI), which is a constitutional body responsible for resolving inter-provincial disputes. Usto said that any dispute over water distribution should be taken to the CCI, which then takes actions to resolve it. Memon, the climate change consultant, said that the relationship between Sindh and the federal government is likely to be strained due to the canal controversy. “Sindh is the stronghold of the Pakistan People’s Party. If the federal government does not reverse its decision [on new canals], there is a strong possibility that the PPP may eventually part ways with the coalition government of Shehbaz Sharif,” Memon told Nikkei. Adnan Aamir is a contributing writer.

title: India rupee erases year’s losses as investors return and tariffs loom
description: The rupee touched a year-to-date high of 85.45 to the dollar on March 24. © Reuters South Asian currency rebounds after slumping to a record low in February SOUMYAJIT SAHA March 26, 2025 14:05 JST MUMBAI — The rupee has charged to its strongest position against the dollar this year , helped in part by dollar inflows into India and the return of foreign portfolio investors, though the risk of a setback from expected U.S. tariffs remains. The rupee is also this month’s best performing major Asian currency, rising over 2% in March as of Tuesday’s close, ahead of peers like the Singaporean dollar, Philippine peso and Malaysian ringgit. The currency’s rebound comes after it plumbed record lows in February due to slow domestic growth and foreign investors stepping away from Indian assets. On Monday, the rupee touched a year-to-date high of 85.45 to the dollar. On Tuesday and Wednesday, it fell slightly lower though it remained roughly 2.7% above the all-time low of 87.992 it recorded on Feb. 10. In March, the currency has been largely boosted by financial year-end inflows of dollar-denominated corporate profits, while a return of foreign capital into the wider market has also helped, Dhiraj Nim, forex strategist and economist at ANZ bank told Nikkei Asia. Indian companies often repatriate their dollar-based earnings in March. On Tuesday, foreign investors bought nearly $630 million worth of Indian equities, according to provisional data from the National Stock Exchange. That was on top of about $1.3 billion in foreign inflows into equities over the preceding three trading sessions. As for Indian bonds, foreign inflows so far this month have amounted to about $3 billion. The rampant buying comes after months of persistent selling by foreign portfolio managers, including a net withdrawal of about $4 billion from Indian equities in February. On Tuesday, Indian equities’ winning streak reached seven days. All the buying has erased the losses for the calendar year so far, and comes after over $1 trillion was erased from the value of the equity market since its September peak. The trough reflected weak corporate earnings and foreign capital outflows. Despite the recovery, analysts warn the next set of Trump tariffs, set to kick in on April 2, could impact the rupee. “If tariffs come to have a substantial economic impact,” ANZ’s Nim said, “I think the most natural course of action should be to let the rupee weaken, as that can absorb a part of that shock.” India was on a list of countries of “particular interest” to the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative when it requested public comments on trade tariffs. “We estimate India would potentially lose about $6 billion (0.16% of GDP) in exports to the US at 10% broad tariffs, with this rising to about $31 billion at 25% tariffs,” brokerage Emkay Global said in a note on Tuesday. ANZ’s Nim said India’s central bank has allowed the rupee to considerably appreciate, potentially creating “headroom” for depreciation. “If tariffs hit and [the currency] depreciates to 87.5, it is still familiar territory,” he said. “But if it goes beyond 88 or 89, then imported inflation becomes something to worry about. … The RBI rule of thumb is a 5% depreciation (in the rupee) leads to a 35 basis point bump in inflation.”

title: China’s DeepSeek updates V3 model in challenge to OpenAI’s GPT-4.5
description: DeepSeek, symbolic of Chinese AI ingenuity, has helped the Hang Seng Tech Index surge around 25% since the start of 2025. © Reuters Version improves on predecessor and outperforms U.S. rival in some tasks CISSY ZHOU March 26, 2025 11:38 JST HONG KONG — Chinese AI startup DeepSeek quietly released an update to its V3 large language model on Tuesday evening, significantly enhancing its reasoning capabilities and further escalating competition with U.S. rival OpenAI. Dubbed DeepSeek-V3-0324, the updated model has improved significantly over its predecessor, especially in advanced math and coding, according to the company’s post on Hugging Face, a U.S. open-source AI community. Benchmark tests show DeepSeek’s latest model outperforms GPT-4.5 in coding and mathematical reasoning, while GPT-4.5 remains the strongest overall in knowledge-based tasks. The new V3 model further optimizes the writing level of Chinese writing tasks based on its R1 model, with a particular focus on improving the content quality of medium-to-long-form text creation, according to DeepSeek. “From a purely technical perspective, there isn’t a major breakthrough in DeepSeek’s update compared to its previous versions, and I think all models will continue to update rapidly, but the impact won’t be as significant as the leap from zero to one,” said Eugene Lee, a Hong Kong-based AI engineer. “However, as an open-source model, DeepSeek’s updated capabilities matching GPT-4.5 are relatively rare,” he said. After taking the tech world by storm in January with its cheap-to-train but robust AI model, DeepSeek has become the poster child for Chinese AI ingenuity. The startup’s meteoric rise has rekindled optimism about Chinese innovation and bolstered Beijing’s commitment to supporting its tech players. DeepSeek founder Liang Wenfeng and Alibaba co-founder Jack Ma were among the Chinese tech entrepreneurs who attended a high-profile gathering with Chinese President Xi Jinping last month, further fueling a tech market rally around China’s AI advancement. The Hang Seng Tech Index has surged around 25% since the start of the year.

title: South Korea’s ‘worst-ever’ wildfires kill at least 18
description: A firefighter works to extinguish flames at a house that has been engulfed by a wildfire in Uiseong, South Korea, on March 25.  © AP Acting president says nation is mobilizing all available resources to minimize casualties STEVEN BOROWIEC March 26, 2025 11:31 JST SEOUL — Strong winds are driving wildfires in southeastern South Korea, fueling what the country’s acting president is calling the most damaging blazes in the country’s history. Han Duck-soo said Wednesday that 18 people, including four firefighters, have died in the fires and 23,000 people were evacuated from their homes. He added that 244 wildfires have occurred in South Korea this year, 2.4 times more than by the same time last year. Also, 17,000 hectares of woodland and 209 locations, such as homes and factories, have been destroyed. To combat the fires, Han said 4,652 personnel have been activated, as well as 128 helicopters, with additional support from the U.S. military stationed in South Korea. “We are fighting the worst wildfires in history using all the manpower and equipment that we can mobilize but the situation is dire,” Han said, according to a release from his office. Han expressed thanks to all emergency personnel and government workers who are engaged in battling and dealing with the fallout from the blazes. “The whole nation is watching as you work to protect your hometowns, your families and your neighbors,” he said. Wildfires tend to occur in the spring in South Korea, a time of strong winds and dry weather conditions. Officials have not pinpointed a cause of this year’s exceptionally severe blazes, but Han said Wednesday that fires lit by locals to incinerate waste are the main cause of wildfires. This week’s weather forecast is for continued dry conditions and only a low chance of rain. The disaster is taking place at a time of political chaos in South Korea, created by President Yoon Suk Yeol’s botched attempt at instituting emergency martial law in early December. Yoon is currently awaiting a Constitutional Court verdict that will either formally remove or return him to office. He was impeached in December and a verdict in his case has been hotly anticipated for weeks, since the court held its final hearing in his case in late February. Han resumed duties as acting president on Monday when the same court that will rule on Yoon’s fate decided to reject his impeachment and restore him to office. Opposition lawmakers voted to impeach Han in December, after he was named acting leader following Yoon’s impeachment.

title: Trump administration hits China with slew of tech export controls
description: U.S. President Donald Trump's administration has added more than 50 Chinese companies to an export control list. © Reuters Move targets advanced computing and hypersonic weapon capabilities KENJI KAWASE March 26, 2025 11:18 JST HONG KONG — U.S. President Donald Trump’s administration has significantly expanded the trade blacklist it inherited from the previous Joe Biden team, aiming to further constrict China’s capabilities to develop artificial intelligence and advanced computing, as well as direct military technologies like hypersonic missiles. The Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) of the U.S. Commerce Department has added 80 organizations to the Entity List for actions “contrary to U.S. national security and foreign policy.” The additions to the blacklist include entities from the United Arab Emirates, South Africa, Iran and even Taiwan, but most are either Chinese or linked to China. BIS, in an announcement released Tuesday in Washington, identified a key objective of preventing the Chinese Communist Party from gaining the ability to “acquire and develop high-performance and exascale computing capabilities, as well as quantum technologies, for military applications.” Exascale computing is the latest supercomputer technology enabling further development of AI. It describes computing at speeds of at least 1 exaflop, or 1 quintillion floating-point calculations per second. Another goal was to “impede China’s development of its hypersonic weapons program,” essentially, weapons that travel five times the speed of sound or faster and boast enhanced maneuverability to evade defenses. Military vehicles carrying DF-17 hypersonic missiles drive past Beijing’s Tiananmen Square during a National Day parade in October 2019.   © Reuters “American technology should never be used against the American people,” Jeffrey I. Kessler, undersecretary for industry and security at the Commerce Department, said in the statement. He stressed that the Trump administration is “sending a clear, resounding message” to safeguard national security “by preventing U.S. technologies and goods from being misused for high-performance computing, hypersonic missiles, military aircraft training, and UAVs that threaten our national security.” The Commerce Department also listed the Test Flying Academy of South Africa (TFASA) to prevent the use of “U.S. items to train Chinese military forces.” Apart from China, the expanded list is also intended to “disrupt Iran’s procurement of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and related defense items.” Kessler added that the Entity List is “one of many powerful tools at our disposal to identify and cut off foreign adversaries seeking to exploit American technology for malign purposes.” China had not responded to the U.S. announcement as of publication time.

title: Russia and Ukraine agree to ensure safe navigation in Black Sea, U.S. says
description: Ukraine's coast guard on patrol as a cargo ship passes by in the Black Sea in 2024. © Reuters Moscow wants Washington to 'order' Kyiv to follow deal March 26, 2025 01:55 JST WASHINGTON/MOSCOW/KYIV (Reuters) — The United States said on Tuesday it has reached separate agreements with Ukraine and Russia to ensure safe navigation in the Black Sea and to implement a ban on attacks by the two countries on each other’s energy facilities. The agreements, if implemented, would represent the clearest progress yet toward a wider ceasefire that Washington sees as a steppingstone toward peace talks to bring an end to Russia’s 3-year-old war in Ukraine. Russia, however, said it could not trust Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and it could therefore only sign a Black Sea deal if Washington issued an “order” to him to respect it. “We will need clear guarantees. And given the sad experience of agreements with just Kyiv, the guarantees can only be the result of an order from Washington to Zelenskyy and his team to do one thing and not the other,” Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov said in televised comments. It was not immediately clear whether Moscow’s demand risked derailing the deal. Zelenskyy has previously said Russian President Vladimir Putin, who sent his army into Ukraine in February 2022, is not to be trusted over peace moves. Ukrainian Defense Minister Rustem Umerov said Kyiv had agreed to both a maritime ceasefire and a pause by Russia and Ukraine in attacks on each other’s energy infrastructure. But he said Kyiv would regard any movement of Russian military vessels outside the eastern part of the Black Sea as a violation and a threat. In this case Ukraine would have the full right to exercise self-defense, he said. Seeking to fulfill a pledge by President Donald Trump to end the war quickly, the U.S. originally proposed a full 30-day ceasefire — to which Ukraine agreed in principle on March 11 — as a step toward peace talks. But the Americans held separate talks in Saudi Arabia with Russia and Ukraine this week to discuss more limited ceasefires on energy and at sea, after Putin responded to the wider truce plan with a long list of conditions and questions. Trump is pressing both sides to bring a swift end to the war, something he promised to achieve when he ran for president last year. At the same time he is pursuing a rapid rapprochement with Moscow that both sides say could lead to lucrative business opportunities and cooperation across a wide range of areas, from minerals to sports and space exploration. Ukraine and its European allies fear Trump could strike a hasty deal with Putin that undermines their security and caves in to Russian demands, including for Kyiv to abandon its NATO ambitions and give up the entirety of four regions claimed by Russia as its own. Ukraine has rejected that as tantamount to surrender.

title: Ancient wasp may have used its rear end to trap flies
description: Bizarre parasitic wasps preserved in amber about 99 million years ago had trap-like abdomens that they may have used to immobilise other insects

title: GLP-1 drugs are only the start – the powerful drugs to expect next
description: The race is under way to make faster, cheaper and better GLP-1 drugs that will go beyond reducing obesity levels to treating some of our most difficult conditions

title: Pregnancy’s lasting effects on different parts of the body revealed
description: An "unprecedented view" of how the body changes during and after pregnancy has revealed many long-lasting impacts on the liver, kidneys and more

title: The Ozempic era is only just beginning
description: In the past year, treatments such as Wegovy, Mounjaro and Zepbound have become household names. But there are many questions left to answer, not least what the future holds for weight-loss medications and society at large

title: Why do giraffes have spots? Not for the reason you might think
description: The size and shape of a giraffe’s spots seem to influence how well the animals survive when temperatures get hotter or colder than normal

title: The unexpected impacts of a society transformed by weight-loss drugs
description: Drugs like Ozempic and Wegovy have the power to block the forces driving obesity, but the knock-on societal effects may not necessarily be so positive

title: An early hint of cosmic dawn has been seen in a distant galaxy
description: A galaxy inside a bubble may be evidence that the universe was starting to become transparent 330 million years after the big bang

title: Why exercise is more important than ever when taking weight-loss drugs
description: GLP-1 drugs have revolutionised the treatment of obesity, but the very reason they are effective is also why it's vital to prioritise exercise when taking them

title: Microdosing weight-loss drugs is on the rise – but does it work?
description: There are many claims about the benefits of microdosing weight-loss drugs, from anti-inflammatory effects to extending longevity. Do any of them stack up?

title: Mathematician wins 2025 Abel prize for tools to solve tricky equations
description: Masaki Kashiwara has won the 2025 Abel prize, seen by some as the Nobel of mathematics, for his contributions to algebraic analysis and representation theory

title: What do GLP-1 drugs really tell us about the brain's reward system?
description: Anecdotal reports suggest drugs like Ozempic may curb not just appetite but also impulsive or addictive behaviour, hinting at links between metabolic health and our brains

title: We may have found the edge of quantum theory – what’s beyond it?
description: Researchers have identified the border between quantum physics and some as-yet-unknown post-quantum realm by mathematically analysing all possible measurements of simple quantum systems

title: Wood made transparent using rice and egg whites could replace windows
description: Transparent wood, made by stripping organic polymers and replacing them with a mixture of egg whites and rice extract, could be used as windows and smartphone screens

title: Sharks aren’t silent after all
description: A species of houndshark called Mustelus lenticulatus makes sharp clicking noises when handled. Until now, sharks as a group were thought to be universally quiet

title: Fake pills ease PMS symptoms even when you know they're placebos
description: Women with premenstrual syndrome reported big improvements in their symptoms after taking placebo pills, despite knowing they did not contain any active ingredients

title: Leading AI models fail new test of artificial general intelligence
description: A new test of AI capabilities consists of puzzles that humans are able to solve without too much trouble, but which all leading AI models struggle with. To improve and pass the test, AI companies will need to balance problem-solving abilities with cost.

title: Floating wood could help us refreeze the Arctic seas
description: Floating platforms of wood could draw up seawater and help it to freeze, seeding the formation of new sea ice

title: Foie gras made without force-feeding thanks to molecular mimicry
description: Scientists have replicated the luxurious mouthfeel of foie gras using the liver and fat of ducks reared and slaughtered normally, avoiding the controversial techniques involved in traditional production

title: Ex-UK cyber chief says asking Apple to break encryption was 'naive'
description: Ciaran Martin, the former head of cyber security at GCHQ, says the UK government was "naive" to expect a request for Apple to weaken its encryption services to remain secret. He thinks governments must come to terms with the fact that uncrackable encryption is here to stay.

title: Smartphones may be beneficial to children – if they avoid social media
description: In the ongoing debate over the benefits and harms of smartphone use in children, initial data from a US survey suggests the devices can actually improve well-being and social connections, but social media use may be more harmful

title: Even moderate CO2 emissions could lead to 7°C of warming by 2200
description: There's a small chance of very high warming even with moderate future emissions, according to a computer model exploring what could happen in the next thousand years

title: How a surprising twist on rewilding could help settle our carbon debt
description: We’ve pumped huge amounts of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere that needs to be paid back. Large animals like wolves, bison and whales may already be tackling the problem

title: Water can turn into a superacid that makes diamonds
description: Simulations suggest that water can become a superacid under extremely high heat and pressure conditions. This may also explain how planets like Uranus and Neptune get diamond rain

title: Greenland has gained over 1600 km of new coastline as glaciers retreat
description: Melting ice is revealing new coastal zones in the Arctic, but while this new landscape might fuel speculation about natural resources, it is vulnerable to rockfalls and landslides that can cause dangerous tsunamis

title: Bizarre fossil may have been an entirely new type of life
description: Chemical analysis suggests the 400-million-year-old fossil Prototaxites was neither plant, animal or fungus – hinting at a mysterious life form that went extinct long ago

title: We’re finally learning how perimenopause profoundly changes the brain
description: The hormonal upheaval in the run-up to menopause can cause cognitive difficulties. But researchers are also finding that this can be a critical window for protecting long-term brain health

title: Why you don't need to worry about 'over-potting' your plants
description: Traditional advice tells us to only move growing plants to a pot one size larger. The science shows that you don't need to bother with this slow transition, says James Wong

title: Is our cosmos just a membrane on the edge of a far stranger reality?
description: String theory may be our best attempt at a theory of everything, except that it can't describe an expanding universe like ours. Now a radical new twist on the idea could finally fix that – but it requires us to completely reimagine reality

title: Psychology is revealing how to have a better relationship with money
description: Money is a deeply emotive subject, our attitudes to it vary wildly and we are reluctant to bring it up in conversation. Could new research help us to be less weird about it?

title: What the extraordinary medical know-how of wild animals can teach us
description: Birds do it, chimps do it, even monarch butterflies do it – and by paying more attention to how animals self-medicate, we can find new treatments for ourselves

title: New Scientist recommends Weather Girl, an electrifying one-woman show
description: Weather Girl, a play in London's Soho Theatre about a weather forecaster who finally snaps as the climate apocalypse looms, is frantic and funny

title: Brilliant sci-fi novel shows robots coming to grips with emancipation
description: Abigail is created to replace her owner's dead wife, just as robots are set to gain rights. Emily H. Wilson explores Lucy Lapinska's Some Body Like Me, the latest addition to "robo-rights" literature

title: Relics in Tutankhamun’s tomb hint he invented elaborate burial rites
description: Tutankhamun ruled ancient Egypt shortly after a period of religious instability, and objects from his tomb suggest he took advantage to invent new funerary rituals

title: Why it would be utter madness to stop funding mRNA vaccine technology
description: It's not a just a revolutionary and safe vaccine technology – mRNA could help make the best and most expensive drugs in the world affordable for everyone

title: NASA has made the first radio telescope observations on the moon
description: The Odysseus spacecraft made a rough landing on the moon last year, toppling over and rendering much of its equipment unusable, but an onboard NASA radio telescope called ROLSES-1 was able to make some observations

title: Classrooms decorated like woodlands seem to slow myopia progression
description: Spending a lot of time outdoors may be the best way to prevent myopia, or delay its progression, but this isn't always practical. Now, research suggests that bringing the outside in may be a valid workaround

title: Why you should slow down your brain’s ageing – and how to do it
description: Many of us have a brain that is older than our years. But there are plenty of things you can do to counteract this, says neuroscience columnist Helen Thomson

title: German company set for first commercial rocket launch from Europe
description: Isar Aerospace is preparing to launch its Spectrum rocket from a base in Norway, which would make it the first orbital launch from continental Europe outside Russia

title: A radical new idea for how our ancestors invented stone tools
description: Stone tools are considered the first form of technology devised by ancient humans – but they might not have been invented from scratch

title: AI can forecast the weather in seconds without needing supercomputers
description: While earlier weather-forecasting AIs have replaced some tasks done by traditional models, new research uses machine learning to replace the entire process, making it much faster

title: Ancient clay tablets offer vivid portrait of Mesopotamian life
description: When a vast library of texts amassed by Mesopotamian King Ashurbanipal was burned to the ground about 2700 years ago, the clay tablets were preserved by the heat. Selena Wisnom's new book reveals more

title: What happened when one woman set out to improve her personality
description: In the enjoyable and science-backed book Me, But Better, Olga Khazan embarks on a year-long experiment to see if she can really become a more agreeable person

title: Monkeys choose babysitters based on who has more parenting experience
description: Young female black-and-white snub-nosed monkeys often want to hold other females’ infants, but mothers are much more permissive of experienced caregivers

title: Nuclear fusion fuel could be made greener with new chemical process
description: Lithium-6 is a crucial material for nuclear fusion reactors, but isolating it is challenging – now researchers have found a way to do this without using toxic mercury

title: Two-fingered dinosaur used its enormous claws to eat leaves
description: A dinosaur fossil discovered in Mongolia boasts the largest ever complete claw, but the herbivorous species only used it to grasp vegetation

title: Scientists push back against US attacks on science at physics summit
description: At the largest gathering of physicists in the world, the American Physical Society says it won’t back down in the face of executive orders to limit diversity programmes

title: Why particle physicists are going wild for a record-breaking neutrino
description: Last month's discovery of the most energetic neutrino yet detected is incredibly exciting for us particle physicists – but it also raises many questions, says Chanda Prescod-Weinstein

title: Is this new Lego model a nod to the terrifying idea of mirror life?
description: Feedback, a Lego fan, delves into a new science-related set, and learns that the model of a DNA double helix is the wrong way around. Time for some jokes about mirror organisms...

title: An early-warning system for climate 'tipping points' is an awful idea
description: Improving our understanding of sudden climate shifts is welcome. But framing this as creating an "early-warning system" is wrong on so many levels it is hard to know where to begin, says Bill McGuire

title: Tattoos are being linked to some cancers. Are they really a risk?
description: Having a tattoo has been linked to a higher risk of conditions like lymphoma and skin cancer, but the situation isn't clear-cut

title: This excellent guide to the science of uncertainty is very welcome
description: Adam Kucharski's new book Proof is a life raft in a sea of fake news and misinformation

title: Dark energy isn't what we thought – and that may transform the cosmos
description: Our current best theories of the universe suggest that dark energy is making it expand faster and faster, but new observations from the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument suggest this mysterious force is actually growing weaker

title: Popular TikTok videos about ADHD are full of misinformation
description: The top 100 videos about ADHD on TikTok feature many claims that psychologists consider inaccurate, but students often identify misleading videos as helpful

title: Microsoft’s quantum computer hit with criticism at key physics meeting
description: After weeks of criticism, Microsoft promised to show new data about its Majorana 1 quantum computer at the biggest meeting of the world's physicists. Researchers in the room tell New Scientist they were not impressed with what they saw.

title: Budgie brains have a map of vocal sounds just like humans
description: Recordings of brain activity in budgerigars reveal sets of brain cells that represent different sounds like keys on a keyboard – a structure never seen before in any bird brain

title: Quantum satellite sets globe-spanning distance record
description: A record-setting test of quantum communication used a microsatellite to connect ground stations in China and South Africa, bringing a global quantum internet closer to reality

title: Microdosing LSD is not an effective ADHD treatment
description: The first randomised controlled trial of microdosing LSD as a treatment for ADHD found the psychedelic drug wasn’t any more effective than a placebo in alleviating symptoms

title: Euclid space telescope captures 26 million galaxies in first data drop
description: The European Space Agency has released the first batch of large-scale images from the Euclid space telescope, which astronomers have already used to find hundreds of strong gravitational lenses

title: The world's climate is in uncharted territory, warns major report
description: A World Meteorological Organization report details a long list of grim records for everything from CO2 levels and temperature to sea ice loss and sea level rise

title: Weird meteorite may be relic of lost planet that no longer exists
description: A meteorite discovered in north-west Africa in 2023 didn’t come from a large asteroid or any of the known planets of the solar system – but it might have formed on a planet that was destroyed long ago

title: Will we soon be able to charge electric cars in minutes?
description: Speedy new chargers from Chinese automaker BYD take just 5 minutes to restore 400 kilometres of an electric car’s range, but will they be widely used?

title: Surprising skeletons prompt a radical rethink of Egyptian pyramids
description: For years, Egyptologists have assumed pyramid tombs were just for the rich – but the burials at a site called Tombos don’t fit this pattern

title: Best ever map of early universe is double-edged sword for cosmologists
description: The finest ever map of the cosmic microwave background - the faint evidence of the universe's early form - has yielded precise confirmation of the age of the cosmos and its rate of expansion. But for some scientists, the findings offer a frustrating lack of clues to major cosmological mysteries

title: New evidence microbes played a role in mysterious markings on Mars
description: There are a couple potential explanations for distinctive markings found on a Martian rock, but new evidence suggests they are most likely to be related to microbial activity

title: Dust devils on Mars produce lightning-like zaps of electricity
description: NASA’s Perseverance rover recorded unusual sounds as a Martian dust devil passed directly over the robotic vehicle in 2021, and we now know they came from electrical activity in the storm

title: Have we vastly underestimated the total number of people on Earth?
description: A new way of estimating rural populations has found that we may be undercounting people who live in these areas, potentially inflating the global population beyond the official count of 8.2 billion – but not everyone agrees

title: Gravity may arise from quantumness of space
description: Scientists have long sought the particle that carries the force of gravity, but a new theoretical model tosses out that idea entirely – and shows how it could be tested in experiments

title: Most quakes on Mars happen during the summer – and we don’t know why
description: NASA’s InSight lander recorded surprisingly large quakes that indicate Mars is more seismically active than we first thought. Mysteriously, they only happen during Martian summers

title: LHC finds intriguing new clues about our universe's antimatter mystery
description: Analysing the aftermath of particle collisions has revealed two new instances of “CP violation”, a process that explains why our universe contains more matter than antimatter

title: Rolling boulders on Titan could threaten NASA's Dragonfly mission
description: The wind on Saturn's largest moon is strong enough to blow around rocks of up to half a metre in diameter, which could put NASA's upcoming Dragonfly mission at risk

title: How a start-up plans to mine the moon for a rare form of helium
description: A private moon mission planned for 2027 will be the first step towards commercial lunar mining of rare and expensive helium-3

title: Giant Milky Way-like galaxy formed unusually soon after the big bang
description: The Big Wheel, discovered using the James Webb Space Telescope, formed just 2 billion years after the big bang - surprisingly early for a spiral galaxy of a similar size to our Milky Way

title: Mathematicians solve 125-year-old problem to unite key laws of physics
description: Can one single mathematical framework describe the motion of a fluid and the individual particles within it? This question, first asked in 1900, now has a solution that could help us understand the complex behaviour of the atmosphere and oceans.

title: What makes a good day a good day, according to science
description: Surveys that ask thousands of people how they spend their time have revealed some surprising activities that seem to make any given day a good one

title: How breaking the rules of tic-tac-toe makes it way more fun
description: Noughts and crosses, or tic-tac-toe, is a simple game – but twist the rules and you can really spice it up, says Peter Rowlett

title: A fresh understanding of tiredness reveals how to get your energy back
description: Radical new insights from the science of interoception – how the body senses its internal state – explain the real reasons we feel tired all the time, and how to re-energise

title: The epic scientific quest to reveal what makes folktales so compelling
description: Linguists, psychologists and experts in cultural evolution are discovering why we tell stories, how ancient the oldest ones are and why some tales run and run

title: The physicist on a mission to spark a quantum industrial revolution
description: Quantum fridges, batteries and clocks are brilliant inventions but still limited in power. Now physicist Nicole Yunger Halpern is charting a path to take them to the next level

title: Terrific drama shows the battle for girls' education in Afghanistan
description: The odds are stacked against an all-female robotics team in Rule Breakers, a fantastic film about teaching girls in Afghanistan

title: The surprising new idea behind what sparked life on Earth
description: We may be starting to get a grasp on what kick-started life on Earth – and it could help us search for it on other planets

title: We may have discovered how dark oxygen is being made in the deep sea
description: A newly discovered mechanism could explain the shock finding last year that oxygen is produced by metallic nodules on the seafloor – and it might be happening on other planets, too

title: Starlink satellite part hit a Canadian farm when it fell from orbit
description: A failed launch left a batch of Starlink satellites in the wrong orbit last year, and it appears that a fragment of one fell to Earth and hit a farm in Canada. Thankfully, no one was injured

title: Should governments really be using AI to remake the state?
description: New Scientist's revelation that a UK minister is asking ChatGPT for advice raises the question of what role these new AI tools should play in government – and whether we should really think of them as intelligent

title: Memory illusion makes you think events occurred earlier than they did
description: It can be difficult to recall exactly when a specific event happened, and now it seems our memory can be tricked into pushing occurrences back in time, making us think they happened earlier than in reality

title: Revealed: How the UK tech secretary uses ChatGPT for policy advice
description: New Scientist has used freedom of information laws to obtain the ChatGPT records of Peter Kyle, the UK's technology secretary, in what is believed to be a world-first use of such legislation

title: AI scientists are sceptical that modern models will lead to AGI
description: In a survey of AI researchers, most say current AI models are unlikely to lead to artificial general intelligence with human-level capabilities, even as companies invest billions of dollars in this goal

title: How cloud-seeding could help us predict when it will snow
description: These brilliant images show how researchers in Switzerland are using weather-modification techniques to understand how ice crystals form in clouds, an important and poorly understood factor in climate and weather models

title: More than half of life on Earth experiencing unprecedented conditions
description: An analysis of changes to global ecosystems has revealed that almost nowhere is untouched by the influence of humanity, with more than 50 per cent of the planet's land mass experiencing "novel" conditions

title: Why the long history of calculating pi will never be completed
description: Building the full value of pi has been a project thousands of years in the making, but just how much of this infinite number do we actually need, asks our maths columnist Jacob Aron

title: Hypnotic art has its roots in the terrifying reality of nuclear bombs
description: In his Atomic series, artist James Stanford showcases "the spectacle and the horror" of growing up near a nuclear bomb testing site

title: Exhibition uses art to explore the mysteries of the quantum world
description: Cosmic Titans, a new exhibition at the University of Nottingham, UK, is a powerful collaboration of artists and quantum physicists that sets out to make the intangible tangible

title: You could train your brain to be less fooled by optical illusions
description: Shifting your focus could help you overcome the trickery of optical illusions

title: Adding extra protein to ultra-processed foods helps reduce overeating
description: The health problems associated with ultra-processed foods may be explained by the way the products encourage overeating. Adding more protein to the foods might help people limit their intake – but it isn’t a complete solution

title: NOAA cancels monthly climate and weather update calls
description: The US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration says it is discontinuing its regular update calls due to staffing problems, but its researchers may also fear political retaliation for discussing climate change

title: Fossils reveal what the fur of early mammals looked like
description: A study of the fossilised fur of six mammals from the Jurassic and Cretaceous periods has found they were all greyish-brown in colour, which would have helped them hide from dinosaurs

title: Destruction of Ukraine’s Kakhovka dam left behind a toxic legacy
description: The 2023 breach of the Kakhovka dam drained a huge reservoir and exposed a vast area of toxic sediment, creating a debate about how best to rebuild after the Russia-Ukraine war

title: NASA may have to cancel major space missions due to budget cuts
description: Potential cuts of up to 50 per cent of NASA's science budget could mean cancelling missions including the Hubble Space Telescope and the Voyager probes

title: Ancient humans lived in an 'uninhabitable' climate 25,000 years ago
description: Bones dating back 25,000 years suggest that humans lived in extremely icy conditions in Tibet, which were previously thought to be uninhabitable

title: How we could achieve dog-level sense of smell – and what it would mean
description: Our Future Chronicles column explores an imagined history of inventions yet to come – this time how, by the mid-21st century, many people were opting for a "nose job" that would supercharge their sense of smell. Rowan Hooper is our guide.

title: Hera asteroid mission takes stunning images of Mars’s moon Deimos
description: A mission to survey the results of a deliberate crash between an asteroid and a NASA spacecraft has taken stunning images of Mars and its moon Deimos

title: Ancient parasitic 'Venus flytrap' wasp preserved in amber reveals parasitoid strategies
description: An extinct lineage of parasitic wasps dating from the mid-Cretaceous period and preserved in amber may have used their Venus flytrap-like abdomen to capture and immobilize their prey.

title: Scientists uncover key mechanism in evolution: Whole-genome duplication drives long-term adaptation
description: Sometimes, the most significant scientific discoveries happen by accident. Scientists have long known that whole-genome duplication (WGD)—the process by which organisms copy all their genetic material—plays an important role in evolution. But understanding just how WGD arises, persists, and drives adaptation has remained poorly understood.

title: Developing a clearer understanding of permafrost thaw risk in Alaska
description: In the Arctic, permafrost plays a crucial role in building infrastructure. However, as the region warms and permafrost thaws, infrastructure is threatened as the ground shifts beneath the built environment. Unfortunately, the full extent of the risks associated with this process is not yet realized, but researchers are working to address this knowledge gap.

title: Better than the original: New SQL-based service offers tailored biodiversity data cubes for model integration
description: The Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF) has enabled a simple, easy-to-use service for creating and downloading species occurrence cubes based on GBIF-mediated data. The service enables users to select their geographic, temporal and taxonomic dimensions of interest to generate customized reports summarizing occurrences in a format suitable for use in biodiversity models and indicators. Its implementation is part of the work of the Horizon Europe project B-Cubed (Biodiversity Building Blocks for Policy).

title: Q&A: Researcher discusses elevated risk of extinction for over 22% of native North American pollinators
description: A new study led by NatureServe reveals that more than 22% of native pollinators in North America are at an elevated risk of extinction. This first-of-its-kind, taxonomically diverse assessment evaluated nearly 1,600 species—including bees, beetles, butterflies, moths, flower flies, bats and hummingbirds—shedding light on the growing biodiversity crisis affecting ecosystems and food security.

title: X ad sales expected to grow for first time since Musk takeover
description: Elon Musk's X is on pace for its first year of advertising revenue growth since the billionaire acquired the company in 2022, according to research firm Emarketer—in part because advertisers are reacting to Musk's power in the Donald Trump administration.

title: A homegrown player is worth an extra $4.8M annually to a National Hockey League team, says study
description: Everyone loves a hometown hero, and now, a new UBC Okanagan study has determined that having homegrown players on NHL teams is not only good for the fanbase, it's also good for the owner's wallet.

title: Reverse genetics system enhances vaccine development for African swine fever virus
description: Researchers from the J. Craig Venter Institute (JCVI), the Friedrich-Loeffler-Institut (FLI), and the International Livestock Research Institute (ILRI) have developed a reverse genetics system for African swine fever virus (ASFV). This new system will aid researchers in developing vaccines and in studying the pathogenesis and biology of ASFV, a highly contagious, deadly viral disease affecting domesticated and wild pigs, especially prevalent in Africa, Europe, Asia, and the Caribbean.

title: Theoretical physicists completely determine the statistics of quantum entanglement
description: For the first time, theoretical physicists from the Institute of Theoretical Physics (IPhT) in Paris-Saclay have completely determined the statistics that can be generated by a system using quantum entanglement. This achievement paves the way for exhaustive test procedures for quantum devices.

title: Participatory budgets and referendums can ease populist citizens' frustrations
description: "Angry" citizens often experience a lack of trust in politics and democracy. Governments are doing everything they can to involve this group in democracy again with referendums and participatory budgets. Research by Rosa Kindt shows that this is having an effect: these meetings provide satisfaction and a feeling of being heard, especially among right-wing populist citizens. Kindt's Ph.D. defense will take place on 1 April at Radboud University.

title: Push for AI deregulation could put financial markets at risk
description: As Canada moves toward stronger AI regulation with the proposed Artificial Intelligence and Data Act (AIDA), its southern neighbor appears to be taking the opposite approach.

title: Politicians' attacks on immigrants lack solid evidence—new data set the record straight
description: Immigration has dominated recent election campaigns in countries that include the United Kingdom, France, Germany and the United States.

title: AI-driven teaching methods essential for modern education, researcher says
description: AI is transforming education by reshaping lesson planning, grading, and student engagement. It enables personalized learning, automated feedback, and enhanced student-teacher interactions through technologies such as speech recognition and virtual reality. However, AI is not a universal solution.

title: Virtual reality videos can increase environmental awareness and motivation to donate
description: A group of media psychologists at the University of Cologne, led by Professor Dr. Kai Kaspar has examined the effects of presenting environmental protection documentaries by way of 360° virtual reality (VR) videos compared with the use of other more traditional media forms. VR videos are interactive 360° videos that allow viewers to immerse themselves in a digital environment and explore it from different angles, often with the help of VR headsets or glasses.

title: Machine learning algorithm that predicts properties' values benefits housing market, says study
description: Housing tends to be a key part of household wealth, but despite its importance, it has been difficult to measure the value of a property. In a new article, researchers have studied the impact of a popular machine-learning pricing algorithm on the U.S. housing market. The study found that overall, the algorithm benefited the market.

title: High mortality risk found from increase in hot-dry events in China
description: As global warming intensifies and populations continue to grow, the likelihood of extreme high-temperature events is increasing. Hot–dry compound events, in particular, pose a direct threat to human health. High temperatures can have prolonged and delayed effects on people's health; and under conditions of low relative humidity, the mortality associated with extreme heat rises significantly.

title: Regional trends may explain Hadley circulation intensity discrepancy
description: The Hadley circulation, a fundamental component of Earth's atmospheric system, plays a crucial role in global climate regulation by transporting energy and moisture between the tropics and higher latitudes. However, recent studies have revealed a puzzling discrepancy: while reanalysis data suggest a strengthening of the global zonal mean Hadley circulation intensity, climate model simulations predict a weakening trend. What causes this contradiction?

title: Do narrow‑minded search algorithms cause polarized perceptions?
description: Tulane University and the University of Chicago researchers have conducted research demonstrating that user search habits and the relevance‑based optimization of search engines contribute to the reinforcement of existing beliefs.

title: Why humans have smaller faces than Neanderthals
description: The human face is strikingly distinct from our fossil cousins and ancestors—most notably, it is significantly smaller, and more gracile. However, the reasons behind this change remain largely unknown. A team of researchers led by the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology has investigated why and how our species evolved such a unique facial form.

title: Report: Bridge collapse impacts daily lives of nearly half of Baltimore residents
description: The Francis Scott Key Bridge collapse continues to impact the daily lives of nearly half of Baltimore-area residents, a new report from Johns Hopkins University's 21st Century Cities Initiative has found.

title: Forecasting the future of Southern Ocean ecosystems
description: Ecosystems in the Southern Ocean, the body of water surrounding Antarctica, are under threat from climate change. The area's inhabitants, from whales to krill to phytoplankton, face changes such as a loss in sea ice and rising ocean temperatures. If species that are unique to the area, such as the Antarctic toothfish, dwindle in population as a result, this decrease could affect fishery operations and lead to cascading socioeconomic and geopolitical consequences.

title: To address the environmental polycrisis, the first step is to demand more honesty
description: Climate breakdown is a major threat to life as we know it, but it is just one element of a much wider environmental polycrisis that includes biodiversity loss, energy and pollution, food security, population growth and disease outbreaks.
